17656.text: §¶The vision that Isaiah son of Amoz saw regarding Judah and Jerusalem during the times of the kings of Judah: Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah.

17657.text: ¶Heaven and earth, you’re the jury./_Listen to God’s case:/“I had children and raised them well,/_and they turned on me.

17658.text: /The ox knows who’s boss,/_the mule knows the hand that feeds him,/But not Israel./_My people don’t know up from down.

17659.text: /Shame! Misguided God‐dropouts,/_staggering under their guilt‐baggage,/Gang of miscreants,/_band of vandals—/My people have walked out on me, their God,/_turned their backs on The Holy of Israel,/_walked off and never looked back.

17660.text: ¶“Why bother even trying to do anything with you/_when you just keep to your bullheaded ways?/You keep beating your heads against brick walls./_Everything within you protests against you.

17661.text: /From the bottom of your feet to the top of your head,/_nothing’s working right./Wounds and bruises and running sores—/_untended, unwashed, unbandaged.

17662.text: /Your country is laid waste,/_your cities burned down./Your land is destroyed by outsiders while you watch,/_reduced to rubble by barbarians.

17663.text: /Daughter Zion is deserted—/_like a tumbledown shack on a dead‐end street,/Like a tarpaper shanty on the wrong side of the tracks,/_like a sinking ship abandoned by the rats.

17664.text: /If God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies hadn’t left us a few survivors,/_we’d be as desolate as Sodom, doomed just like Gomorrah.

17665.text: ¶“Listen to my Message,/_you Sodom‐schooled leaders./Receive God’s revelation,/_you Gomorrah‐schooled people.

17666.text: ¶“Why this frenzy of sacrifices?”/_God’s asking./“Don’t you think I’ve had my fill of burnt sacrifices,/_rams and plump grain‐fed calves?/Don’t you think I’ve had my fill/_of blood from bulls, lambs, and goats?

17667.text: /When you come before me,/_whoever gave you the idea of acting like this,/Running here and there, doing this and that—/_all this sheer commotion in the place provided for worship?

17668.text: ¶“Quit your worship charades./_I can’t stand your trivial religious games:/Monthly conferences, weekly Sabbaths, special meetings—/_meetings, meetings, meetings—I can’t stand one more!

17669.text: /Meetings for this, meetings for that. I hate them!/_You’ve worn me out!/I’m sick of your religion, religion, religion,/_while you go right on sinning.

17670.text: /When you put on your next prayer‐performance,/_I’ll be looking the other way./No matter how long or loud or often you pray,/_I’ll not be listening./And do you know why? Because you’ve been tearing/_people to pieces, and your hands are bloody.

17671.text: /Go home and wash up./_Clean up your act./Sweep your lives clean of your evildoings/_so I don’t have to look at them any longer./Say no to wrong./_Learn to do good.

17672.text: /Work for justice./_Help the down‐and‐out./Stand up for the homeless./_Go to bat for the defenseless.

17673.text: §¶“Come. Sit down. Let’s argue this out.”/_This is God’s Message:/“If your sins are blood‐red,/_they’ll be snow‐white./If they’re red like crimson,/_they’ll be like wool.

17674.text: /If you’ll willingly obey,/_you’ll feast like kings.

17675.text: /But if you’re willful and stubborn,/_you’ll die like dogs.”/That’s right. God says so.

17676.text: §¶Oh! Can you believe it? The chaste city/_has become a whore!/She was once all justice,/_everyone living as good neighbors,/And now they’re all/_at one another’s throats.

17677.text: /Your coins are all counterfeits./_Your wine is watered down.

17678.text: /Your leaders are turncoats/_who keep company with crooks./They sell themselves to the highest bidder/_and grab anything not nailed down./They never stand up for the homeless,/_never stick up for the defenseless.

17679.text: ¶This Decree, therefore, of the Master, God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies,/_the Strong One of Israel:/“This is it! I’ll get my oppressors off my back./_I’ll get back at my enemies.

17680.text: /I’ll give you the back of my hand,/_purge the junk from your life, clean you up.

17681.text: /I’ll set honest judges and wise counselors among you/_just like it was back in the beginning./Then you’ll be renamed/_City‐That‐Treats‐People‐Right, the True‐Blue City.”

17682.text: /God’s right ways will put Zion right again./_God’s right actions will restore her penitents.

17683.text: /But it’s curtains for rebels and God‐traitors,/_a dead end for those who walk out on God.

17684.text: /“Your dalliances in those oak grove shrines/_will leave you looking mighty foolish,/All that fooling around in god and goddess gardens/_that you thought was the latest thing.

17685.text: /You’ll end up like an oak tree/_with all its leaves falling off,/Like an unwatered garden,/_withered and brown.

17686.text: /‘The Big Man’ will turn out to be dead bark and twigs,/_and his ‘work,’ the spark that starts the fire/That exposes man and work both/_as nothing but cinders and smoke.”

17687.text: §¶The Message Isaiah got regarding Judah and Jerusalem:

17688.text: ¶There’s a day coming/_when the mountain of God’s House/Will be The Mountain—/_solid, towering over all mountains./All nations will river toward it,

17689.text: /_people from all over set out for it./They’ll say, “Come,/_let’s climb God’s Mountain,/_go to the House of the God of Jacob./He’ll show us the way he works/_so we can live the way we’re made.”/Zion’s the source of the revelation./_God’s Message comes from Jerusalem.

17690.text: /He’ll settle things fairly between nations./_He’ll make things right between many peoples./They’ll turn their swords into shovels,/_their spears into hoes./No more will nation fight nation;/_they won’t play war anymore.

17691.text: /Come, family of Jacob,/_let’s live in the light of God.

17692.text: ¶God, you’ve walked out on your family Jacob/_because their world is full of hokey religion,/Philistine witchcraft, and pagan hocus‐pocus,

17693.text: /_a world rolling in wealth,/Stuffed with things,/_no end to its machines and gadgets,

17694.text: /And gods—gods of all sorts and sizes./_These people make their own gods and worship what they make.

17695.text: /A degenerate race, facedown in the gutter./_Don’t bother with them! They’re not worth forgiving!

17696.text: §¶Head for the hills,/_hide in the caves/From the terror of God,/_from his dazzling presence.

17697.text: ¶People with a big head are headed for a fall,/_pretentious egos brought down a peg./It’s God alone at front‐and‐center/_on the Day we’re talking about,

17698.text: /The Day that God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies/_is matched against all big‐talking rivals,/_against all swaggering big names;

17699.text: /Against all giant sequoias/_hugely towering,/_and against the expansive chestnut;

17700.text: /Against Kilimanjaro and Annapurna,/_against the ranges of Alps and Andes;

17701.text: /Against every soaring skyscraper,/_against all proud obelisks and statues;

17702.text: /Against ocean‐going luxury liners,/_against elegant three‐masted schooners.

17703.text: /The swelled big heads will be punctured bladders,/_the pretentious egos brought down to earth,/Leaving God alone at front‐and‐center/_on the Day we’re talking about.

17704.text: ¶And all those sticks and stones/_dressed up to look like gods/_will be gone for good.

17705.text: ¶Clamber into caves in the cliffs,/_duck into any hole you can find./Hide from the terror of God,/_from his dazzling presence,/When he assumes his full stature on earth,/_towering and terrifying.

17706.text: ¶On that Day men and women will take/_the sticks and stones/They’ve decked out in gold and silver/_to look like gods and then worshiped,/And they will dump them/_in any ditch or gully,

17707.text: /Then run for rock caves/_and cliff hideouts/To hide from the terror of God,/_from his dazzling presence,/When he assumes his full stature on earth,/_towering and terrifying.

17708.text: ¶Quit scraping and fawning over mere humans,/_so full of themselves, so full of hot air!/_Can’t you see there’s nothing to them?

17709.text: §¶The Master, God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies,/_is emptying Jerusalem and Judah/Of all the basic necessities,/_plain bread and water to begin with.

17710.text: /He’s withdrawing police and protection,/_judges and courts,/_pastors and teachers,

17711.text: /_captains and generals,/_doctors and nurses,/_and, yes, even the repairmen and jacks‐of‐all‐trades.

17712.text: /He says, “I’ll put little kids in charge of the city./_Schoolboys and schoolgirls will order everyone around.

17713.text: /People will be at each other’s throats,/_stabbing one another in the back:/Neighbor against neighbor, young against old,/_the no‐account against the well‐respected.

17714.text: /One brother will grab another and say,/_‘You look like you’ve got a head on your shoulders./Do something!/_Get us out of this mess.’

17715.text: /And he’ll say, ‘Me? Not me! I don’t have a clue./_Don’t put me in charge of anything.’

17716.text: ¶“Jerusalem’s on its last legs./_Judah is soon down for the count./Everything people say and do/_is at cross‐purposes with God,/_a slap in my face.

17717.text: /Brazen in their depravity,/_they flaunt their sins like degenerate Sodom./Doom to their eternal souls! They’ve made their bed;/_now they’ll sleep in it.

17718.text: ¶“Reassure the righteous/_that their good living will pay off.

17719.text: /But doom to the wicked! Disaster!/_Everything they did will be done to them.

17720.text: ¶“Skinny kids terrorize my people./_Silly girls bully them around./My dear people! Your leaders are taking you down a blind alley./_They’re sending you off on a wild‐goose chase.”

17721.text: §¶God enters the courtroom./_He takes his place at the bench to judge his people.

17722.text: /God calls for order in the court,/_hauls the leaders of his people into the dock:/“You’ve played havoc with this country./_Your houses are stuffed with what you’ve stolen from the poor.

17723.text: /What is this anyway? Stomping on my people,/_grinding the faces of the poor into the dirt?”/That’s what the Master,/_God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies, says.

17724.text: ¶God says, “Zion women are stuck‐up,/_prancing around in their high heels,/Making eyes at all the men in the street,/_swinging their hips,/Tossing their hair,/_gaudy and garish in cheap jewelry.”

17725.text: /The Master will fix it so those Zion women/_will all turn bald—/Scabby, bald‐headed women./_The Master will do it.

17726.text: ¶The time is coming when the Master will strip them of their fancy baubles—

17727.text: the dangling earrings, anklets and bracelets, combs and mirrors and silk scarves,

17729.text: the rings on their fingers and the rings on their toes,

17730.text: the latest fashions in hats, exotic perfumes and aphrodisiacs, gowns and capes,

17731.text: all the world’s finest in fabrics and design.

17732.text: ¶Instead of wearing seductive scents,/_these women are going to smell like rotting cabbages;/Instead of modeling flowing gowns,/_they’ll be sporting rags;/Instead of their stylish hairdos,/_scruffy heads;/Instead of beauty marks,/_scabs and scars.

17733.text: ¶Your finest fighting men will be killed,/_your soldiers left dead on the battlefield.

17734.text: /The entrance gate to Zion will be clotted/_with people mourning their dead—/A city stooped under the weight of her loss,/_brought to her knees by her sorrows.

17735.text: ¶That will be the day when seven women/_will gang up on one man, saying,/“We’ll take care of ourselves,/_get our own food and clothes./Just give us a child. Make us pregnant/_so we’ll have something to live for!”

17736.text: §¶And that’s when God’s Branch will sprout green and lush. The produce of the country will give Israel’s survivors something to be proud of again. Oh, they’ll hold their heads high!

17737.text: Everyone left behind in Zion, all the discards and rejects in Jerusalem, will be reclassified as “holy”—alive and therefore precious.

17738.text: God will give Zion’s women a good bath. He’ll scrub the bloodstained city of its violence and brutality, purge the place with a firestorm of judgment.

17739.text: ¶Then God will bring back the ancient pillar of cloud by day and the pillar of fire by night and mark Mount Zion and everyone in it with his glorious presence, his immense, protective presence,

17740.text: shade from the burning sun and shelter from the driving rain.

17741.text: §¶I’ll sing a ballad to the one I love,/_a love ballad about his vineyard:/The one I love had a vineyard,/_a fine, well‐placed vineyard.

17742.text: /He hoed the soil and pulled the weeds,/_and planted the very best vines./He built a lookout, built a winepress,/_a vineyard to be proud of./He looked for a vintage yield of grapes,/_but for all his pains he got junk grapes.

17743.text: ¶“Now listen to what I’m telling you,/_you who live in Jerusalem and Judah./What do you think is going on/_between me and my vineyard?

17744.text: /Can you think of anything I could have done/_to my vineyard that I didn’t do?/When I expected good grapes,/_why did I get bitter grapes?

17745.text: ¶“Well now, let me tell you/_what I’ll do to my vineyard:/I’ll tear down its fence/_and let it go to ruin.

17746.text: /I’ll knock down the gate/_and let it be trampled./I’ll turn it into a patch of weeds, untended, uncared for—/_thistles and thorns will take over./I’ll give orders to the clouds:/_‘Don’t rain on that vineyard, ever!’”

17747.text: ¶Do you get it? The vineyard of God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies/_is the country of Israel./All the men and women of Judah/_are the garden he was so proud of./He looked for a crop of justice/_and saw them murdering each other./He looked for a harvest of righteousness/_and heard only the moans of victims.

17748.text: §¶Doom to you who buy up all the houses/_and grab all the land for yourselves—/Evicting the old owners,/_posting no trespassing signs,/Taking over the country,/_leaving everyone homeless and landless.

17749.text: /I overheard God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies say:/“Those mighty houses will end up empty./_Those extravagant estates will be deserted.

17750.text: /A ten‐acre vineyard will produce a pint of wine,/_a fifty‐pound sack of seed, a quart of grain.”

17751.text: ¶Doom to those who get up early/_and start drinking booze before breakfast,/Who stay up all hours of the night/_drinking themselves into a stupor.

17752.text: /They make sure their banquets are well‐furnished/_with harps and flutes and plenty of wine,/But they’ll have nothing to do with the work of God,/_pay no mind to what he is doing.

17753.text: /Therefore my people will end up in exile/_because they don’t know the score./Their “big men” will starve to death/_and the common people die of thirst.

17754.text: /Sheol developed a huge appetite,/_swallowing people nonstop!/Big people and little people alike/_down that gullet, to say nothing of all the drunks.

17755.text: /The down‐and‐out on a par/_with the high‐and‐mighty,/Windbag boasters crumpled,/_flaccid as a punctured bladder.

17756.text: /But by working justice,/_God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies will be a mountain./By working righteousness,/_Holy God will show what “holy” is.

17757.text: /And lambs will graze/_as if they owned the place,/Kids and calves/_right at home in the ruins.

17758.text: ¶Doom to you who use lies to sell evil,/_who haul sin to market by the truckload,

17759.text: /Who say, “What’s God waiting for?/_Let him get a move on so we can see it./Whatever The Holy of Israel has cooked up,/_we’d like to check it out.”

17760.text: ¶Doom to you who call evil good/_and good evil,/Who put darkness in place of light/_and light in place of darkness,/Who substitute bitter for sweet/_and sweet for bitter!

17761.text: ¶Doom to you who think you’re so smart,/_who hold such a high opinion of yourselves!

17762.text: /All you’re good at is drinking—champion boozers/_who collect trophies from drinking bouts

17763.text: /And then line your pockets with bribes from the guilty/_while you violate the rights of the innocent.

17764.text: ¶But they won’t get by with it. As fire eats stubble/_and dry grass goes up in smoke,/Their souls will atrophy,/_their achievements crumble into dust,/Because they said no to the revelation/_of God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies,/Would have nothing to do/_with The Holy of Israel.

17765.text: ¶That’s why God flamed out in anger against his people,/_reached out and knocked them down./The mountains trembled/_as their dead bodies piled up in the streets./But even after that, he was still angry,/_his fist still raised, ready to hit them again.

17766.text: /He raises a flag, signaling a distant nation,/_whistles for people at the ends of the earth./And here they come—/_on the run!

17767.text: /None drag their feet, no one stumbles,/_no one sleeps or dawdles./Shirts are on and pants buckled,/_every boot is spit‐polished and tied.

17768.text: /Their arrows are sharp,/_bows strung,/The hooves of their horses shod,/_chariot wheels greased.

17769.text: /Roaring like a pride of lions,/_the full‐throated roars of young lions,/They growl and seize their prey,/_dragging it off—no rescue for that one!

17770.text: /They’ll roar and roar and roar on that Day,/_like the roar of ocean billows./Look as long and hard as you like at that land,/_you’ll see nothing but darkness and trouble./Every light in the sky/_will be blacked out by the clouds.

17771.text: §¶In the year that King Uzziah died, I saw the Master sitting on a throne—high, exalted!—and the train of his robes filled the Temple.

17772.text: Angel‐seraphs hovered above him, each with six wings. With two wings they covered their faces, with two their feet, and with two they flew.

17773.text: And they called back and forth one to the other, ¶▼Holy, Holy, Holy is God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies./His bright glory fills the whole earth.

17774.text: ¶The foundations trembled at the sound of the angel voices, and then the whole house filled with smoke.

17775.text: I said, ¶▼“Doom! It’s Doomsday!/_I’m as good as dead!/Every word I’ve ever spoken is tainted—/_blasphemous even!/And the people I live with talk the same way,/_using words that corrupt and desecrate./And here I’ve looked God in the face!/_The King! God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies!”

17776.text: ¶Then one of the angel‐seraphs flew to me. He held a live coal that he had taken with tongs from the altar.

17777.text: He touched my mouth with the coal and said, ¶▼“Look. This coal has touched your lips./_Gone your guilt,/_your sins wiped out.”

17778.text: /And then I heard the voice of the Master:/_“Whom shall I send?/_Who will go for us?”/I spoke up,/_“I’ll go./_Send me!”

17779.text: ¶He said, “Go and tell this people: ¶▼“‘Listen hard, but you aren’t going to get it;/_look hard, but you won’t catch on.’

17780.text: /Make these people blockheads,/_with fingers in their ears and blindfolds on their eyes,/So they won’t see a thing,/_won’t hear a word,/So they won’t have a clue about what’s going on/_and, yes, so they won’t turn around and be made whole.”

17781.text: ¶Astonished, I said,/_“And Master, how long is this to go on?”/He said, “Until the cities are emptied out,/_not a soul left in the cities—/Houses empty of people,/_countryside empty of people.

17782.text: /Until I, God, get rid of everyone, sending them off,/_the land totally empty.

17783.text: /And even if some should survive, say a tenth,/_the devastation will start up again./The country will look like pine and oak forest/_with every tree cut down—/Every tree a stump, a huge field of stumps./_But there’s a holy seed in those stumps.”

17784.text: §¶During the time that Ahaz son of Jotham, son of Uzziah, was king of Judah, King Rezin of Aram and King Pekah son of Remaliah of Israel attacked Jerusalem, but the attack sputtered out.

17785.text: When the Davidic government learned that Aram had joined forces with Ephraim (that is, Israel), Ahaz and his people were badly shaken. They shook like trees in the wind.

17786.text: ¶Then God told Isaiah, “Go and meet Ahaz. Take your son Shear‐jashub (A‐Remnant‐Will‐Return) with you. Meet him south of the city at the end of the aqueduct where it empties into the upper pool on the road to the public laundry.

17787.text: Tell him, Listen, calm down. Don’t be afraid. And don’t panic over these two burnt‐out cases, Rezin of Aram and the son of Remaliah.

17788.text: They talk big but there’s nothing to them. Aram, along with Ephraim’s son of Remaliah, have plotted to do you harm.

17789.text: They’ve conspired against you, saying, ‘Let’s go to war against Judah, dismember it, take it for ourselves, and set the son of Tabeel up as a puppet king over it.’

17790.text: ¶But God, the Master, says,¶“It won’t happen./_Nothing will come of it

17791.text: /Because the capital of Aram is Damascus/_and the king of Damascus is a mere man, Rezin./As for Ephraim, in sixty‐five years/_it will be rubble, nothing left of it.

17792.text: /The capital of Ephraim is Samaria,/_and the king of Samaria is the mere son of Remaliah./If you don’t take your stand in faith,/_you won’t have a leg to stand on.”

17794.text: This time he said, “Ask for a sign from your God. Ask anything. Be extravagant. Ask for the moon!”

17795.text: ¶But Ahaz said, “I’d never do that. I’d never make demands like that on God!”

17796.text: ¶So Isaiah told him, “Then listen to this, government of David! It’s bad enough that you make people tired with your pious, timid hypocrisies, but now you’re making God tired.

17797.text: So the Master is going to give you a sign anyway. Watch for this: A girl who is presently a virgin will get pregnant. She’ll bear a son and name him Immanuel (God‐With‐Us).

17798.text: By the time the child is twelve years old, able to make moral decisions, the threat of war will be over.

17799.text: Relax, those two kings that have you so worried will be out of the picture. But also be warned:

17800.text: God will bring on you and your people and your government a judgment worse than anything since the time the kingdom split, when Ephraim left Judah. The king of Assyria is coming!”

17801.text: ¶That’s when God will whistle for the flies at the headwaters of Egypt’s Nile, and whistle for the bees in the land of Assyria.

17802.text: They’ll come and infest every nook and cranny of this country. There’ll be no getting away from them.

17803.text: ¶And that’s when the Master will take the razor rented from across the Euphrates—the king of Assyria no less!—and shave the hair off your heads and genitals, leaving you shamed, exposed, and denuded. He’ll shave off your beards while he’s at it.

17804.text: ¶It will be a time when survivors will count themselves lucky to have a cow and a couple of sheep.

17805.text: At least they’ll have plenty of milk! Whoever’s left in the land will learn to make do with the simplest foods—curds, whey, and honey.

17806.text: ¶But that’s not the end of it. This country that used to be covered with fine vineyards—thousands of them, worth millions!—will revert to a weed patch.

17808.text: Good for nothing except, perhaps, hunting rabbits. Cattle and sheep will forage as best they can in the fields of weeds—but there won’t be a trace of all those fertile and well‐tended gardens and fields.

17809.text: ¶Then God told me, “Get a big sheet of paper and write in indelible ink, ‘This belongs to Maher‐shalal‐hash‐baz (Spoil‐Speeds‐Plunder‐Hurries).’”

17810.text: ¶I got two honest men, Uriah the priest and Zechariah son of Jeberekiah, to witness the document. Then I went home to my wife, the prophetess. She conceived and gave birth to a son.

17812.text: Before that baby says ‘Daddy’ or ‘Mamma’ the king of Assyria will have plundered the wealth of Damascus and the riches of Samaria.”

17813.text: ¶God spoke to me again, saying:¶“Because this people has turned its back

17814.text: /_on the gently flowing stream of Shiloah/And gotten all excited over Rezin/_and the son of Remaliah,

17815.text: /I’m stepping in and facing them with/_the wild floodwaters of the Euphrates,/The king of Assyria and all his fanfare,/_a river in flood, bursting its banks,

17816.text: /Pouring into Judah, sweeping everything before it,/_water up to your necks,/A huge wingspan of a raging river,/_O Immanuel, spreading across your land.”

17817.text: ¶But face the facts, all you oppressors, and then wring your hands./_Listen, all of you, far and near./Prepare for the worst and wring your hands./_Yes, prepare for the worst and wring your hands!/Plan and plot all you want—nothing will come of it.

17818.text: /_All your talk is mere talk, empty words,/Because when all is said and done,/_the last word is Immanuel—God‐With‐Us.

17819.text: §¶God spoke strongly to me, grabbed me with both hands and warned me not to go along with this people. He said:

17820.text: ¶“Don’t be like this people,/_always afraid somebody is plotting against them./Don’t fear what they fear.

17821.text: /_Don’t take on their worries./If you’re going to worry,/_worry about The Holy. Fear God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies.

17822.text: /The Holy can be either a Hiding Place/_or a Boulder blocking your way,/The Rock standing in the willful way/_of both houses of Israel,/A barbed‐wire Fence preventing trespass/_to the citizens of Jerusalem.

17823.text: /Many of them are going to run into that Rock/_and get their bones broken,/Get tangled up in that barbed wire/_and not get free of it.”

17824.text: ¶Gather up the testimony,/_preserve the teaching for my followers,

17825.text: /While I wait for God as long as he remains in hiding,/_while I wait and hope for him./I stand my ground and hope,

17826.text: /_I and the children God gave me as signs to Israel,/Warning signs and hope signs from God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies,/_who makes his home in Mount Zion.

17827.text: ¶When people tell you, “Try out the fortunetellers./_Consult the spiritualists./Why not tap into the spirit‐world,/_get in touch with the dead?”

17828.text: /Tell them, “No, we’re going to study the Scriptures.”

17829.text: /_People who try the other ways get nowhere—a dead end!/Frustrated and famished,/_they try one thing after another./When nothing works out they get angry,/_cursing first this god and then that one,

17830.text: /Looking this way and that,/_up, down, and sideways—and seeing nothing,/A blank wall, an empty hole./_They end up in the dark with nothing.

17831.text: §¶But there’ll be no darkness for those who were in trouble. Earlier he did bring the lands of Zebulun and Naphtali into disrepute, but the time is coming when he’ll make that whole area glorious— the road along the Sea, the country past the Jordan, international Galilee.

17832.text: ¶The people who walked in darkness/_have seen a great light./For those who lived in a land of deep shadows—/_light! sunbursts of light!

17833.text: /You repopulated the nation,/_you expanded its joy./Oh, they’re so glad in your presence!/_Festival joy!/The joy of a great celebration,/_sharing rich gifts and warm greetings.

17834.text: /The abuse of oppressors and cruelty of tyrants—/_all their whips and cudgels and curses—/Is gone, done away with, a deliverance/_as surprising and sudden as Gideon’s old victory over Midian.

17835.text: /The boots of all those invading troops,/_along with their shirts soaked with innocent blood,/Will be piled in a heap and burned,/_a fire that will burn for days!

17836.text: /For a child has been born—for us!/_the gift of a son—for us!/He’ll take over/_the running of the world./His names will be: Amazing Counselor,/_Strong God,/Eternal Father,/_Prince of Wholeness.

17837.text: /His ruling authority will grow,/_and there’ll be no limits to the wholeness he brings./He’ll rule from the historic David throne/_over that promised kingdom./He’ll put that kingdom on a firm footing/_and keep it going/With fair dealing and right living,/_beginning now and lasting always./The zeal of God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies/_will do all this.

17838.text: §¶The Master sent a message against Jacob./_It landed right on Israel’s doorstep.

17839.text: /All the people soon heard the message,/_Ephraim and the citizens of Samaria./But they were a proud and arrogant bunch./_They dismissed the message, saying,/“Things aren’t that bad./_We can handle anything that comes.

17840.text: /If our buildings are knocked down,/_we’ll rebuild them bigger and finer./If our forests are cut down,/_we’ll replant them with finer trees.”

17841.text: ¶So God incited their adversaries against them,/_stirred up their enemies to attack:

17842.text: /From the east, Arameans; from the west, Philistines./_They made hash of Israel./But even after that, he was still angry,/_his fist still raised, ready to hit them again.

17843.text: ¶But the people paid no mind to him who hit them,/_didn’t seek God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies.

17844.text: /So God hacked off Israel’s head and tail,/_palm branch and reed, both on the same day.

17845.text: /The big‐head elders were the head,/_the lying prophets were the tail.

17846.text: /Those who were supposed to lead this people/_led them down blind alleys,/And those who followed the leaders/_ended up lost and confused.

17847.text: /That’s why the Master lost interest in the young men,/_had no feeling for their orphans and widows./All of them were godless and evil,/_talking filth and folly./And even after that, he was still angry,/_his fist still raised, ready to hit them again.

17848.text: ¶Their wicked lives raged like an out‐of‐control fire,/_the kind that burns everything in its path—/Trees and bushes, weeds and grasses—/_filling the skies with smoke.

17849.text: /God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies answered fire with fire,/_set the whole country on fire,/Turned the people into consuming fires,/_consuming one another in their lusts—

17850.text: /Appetites insatiable, stuffing and gorging/_themselves left and right with people and things./But still they starved. Not even their children/_were safe from their rapacious hunger.

17851.text: /Manasseh ate Ephraim, and Ephraim Manasseh,/_and then the two ganged up against Judah./And after that, he was still angry,/_his fist still raised, ready to hit them again.

17852.text: §¶Doom to you who legislate evil,/_who make laws that make victims—¶Laws that make misery for the poor,

17853.text: /_that rob my destitute people of dignity,/Exploiting defenseless widows,/_taking advantage of homeless children.

17854.text: /What will you have to say on Judgment Day,/_when Doomsday arrives out of the blue?/Who will you get to help you?/_What good will your money do you?

17855.text: /A sorry sight you’ll be then, huddled with the prisoners,/_or just some corpses stacked in the street./Even after all this, God is still angry,/_his fist still raised, ready to hit them again.

17856.text: §¶“Doom to Assyria, weapon of my anger./_My wrath is a cudgel in his hands!

17857.text: /I send him against a godless nation,/_against the people I’m angry with./I command him to strip them clean, rob them blind,/_and then push their faces in the mud and leave them.

17858.text: /But Assyria has another agenda;/_he has something else in mind./He’s out to destroy utterly,/_to stamp out as many nations as he can.

17860.text: /_Can’t they do whatever they like?/Didn’t I destroy Calno as well as Carchemish?/_Hamath as well as Arpad? Level Samaria as I did Damascus?

17861.text: /I’ve eliminated kingdoms full of gods/_far more impressive than anything in Jerusalem and Samaria.

17862.text: /So what’s to keep me from destroying Jerusalem/_in the same way I destroyed Samaria and all her god‐idols?’”

17863.text: ¶When the Master has finished dealing with Mount Zion and Jerusalem, he’ll say, “Now it’s Assyria’s turn. I’ll punish the bragging arrogance of the king of Assyria, his high and mighty posturing, the way he goes around saying,

17864.text: ¶“‘I’ve done all this by myself./_I know more than anyone./I’ve wiped out the boundaries of whole countries./_I’ve walked in and taken anything I wanted./I charged in like a bull/_and toppled their kings from their thrones.

17865.text: /I reached out my hand and took all that they treasured/_as easily as a boy taking a bird’s eggs from a nest./Like a farmer gathering eggs from the henhouse,/_I gathered the world in my basket,/And no one so much as fluttered a wing/_or squawked or even chirped.’”

17866.text: ¶Does an ax take over from the one who swings it?/_Does a saw act more important than the sawyer?/As if a shovel did its shoveling by using a ditch digger!/_As if a hammer used the carpenter to pound nails!

17867.text: /Therefore the Master, God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies,/_will send a debilitating disease on his robust Assyrian fighters./Under the canopy of God’s bright glory/_a fierce fire will break out.

17868.text: /Israel’s Light will burst into a conflagration./_The Holy will explode into a firestorm,/And in one day burn to cinders/_every last Assyrian thornbush.

17869.text: /God will destroy the splendid trees and lush gardens./_The Assyrian body and soul will waste away to nothing/_like a disease‐ridden invalid.

17870.text: /A child could count what’s left of the trees/_on the fingers of his two hands.

17871.text: ¶And on that Day also, what’s left of Israel, the ragtag survivors of Jacob, will no longer be fascinated by abusive, battering Assyria. They’ll lean on God, The Holy—yes, truly.

17872.text: The ragtag remnant—what’s left of Jacob—will come back to the Strong God.

17873.text: Your people Israel were once like the sand on the seashore, but only a scattered few will return. Destruction is ordered, brimming over with righteousness.

17874.text: For the Master, God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies, will finish here what he started all over the globe.

17875.text: ¶Therefore the Master, God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies, says: “My dear, dear people who live in Zion, don’t be terrorized by the Assyrians when they beat you with clubs and threaten you with rods like the Egyptians once did.

17876.text: In just a short time my anger against you will be spent and I’ll turn my destroying anger on them.

17877.text: I, God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies, will go after them with a cat‐o’‐nine‐tails and finish them off decisively—as Gideon downed Midian at the rock Oreb, as Moses turned the tables on Egypt.

17878.text: On that day, Assyria will be pulled off your back, and the yoke of slavery lifted from your neck.”

17879.text: ¶Assyria’s on the move: up from Rimmon,/_on to Aiath,/through Migron,/_with a bivouac at Micmash.

17880.text: /They’ve crossed the pass,/_set camp at Geba for the night./Ramah trembles with fright./_Gibeah of Saul has run off.

17881.text: /Cry for help, daughter of Gallim!/_Listen to her, Laishah!/_Do something, Anathoth!

17882.text: /Madmenah takes to the hills./_The people of Gebim flee in panic.

17883.text: /The enemy’s soon at Nob—nearly there!/_In sight of the city he shakes his fist/At the mount of dear daughter Zion,/_the hill of Jerusalem.

17884.text: ¶But now watch this: The Master, God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies,/_swings his ax and lops the branches,/Chops down the giant trees,/_lays flat the towering forest‐on‐the‐march.

17885.text: /His ax will make toothpicks of that forest,/_that Lebanon‐like army reduced to kindling.

17886.text: §¶A green Shoot will sprout from Jesse’s stump,/_from his roots a budding Branch.

17887.text: /The life‐giving Spirit of God will hover over him,/_the Spirit that brings wisdom and understanding,/The Spirit that gives direction and builds strength,/_the Spirit that instills knowledge and Fear‐of‐God.

17888.text: /Fear‐of‐God/_will be all his joy and delight./He won’t judge by appearances,/_won’t decide on the basis of hearsay.

17889.text: /He’ll judge the needy by what is right,/_render decisions on earth’s poor with justice./His words will bring everyone to awed attention./_A mere breath from his lips will topple the wicked.

17890.text: /Each morning he’ll pull on sturdy work clothes and boots,/_and build righteousness and faithfulness in the land.

17891.text: §¶The wolf will romp with the lamb,/_the leopard sleep with the kid./Calf and lion will eat from the same trough,/_and a little child will tend them.

17892.text: /Cow and bear will graze the same pasture,/_their calves and cubs grow up together,/_and the lion eat straw like the ox.

17893.text: /The nursing child will crawl over rattlesnake dens,/_the toddler stick his hand down the hole of a serpent.

17894.text: /Neither animal nor human will hurt or kill/_on my holy mountain./The whole earth will be brimming with knowing God‐Alive,/_a living knowledge of God ocean‐deep, ocean‐wide.

17895.text: ¶On that day, Jesse’s Root will be raised high, posted as a rallying banner for the peoples. The nations will all come to him. His headquarters will be glorious.

17896.text: ¶Also on that day, the Master for the second time will reach out to bring back what’s left of his scattered people. He’ll bring them back from Assyria, Egypt, Pathros, Ethiopia, Elam, Sinar, Hamath, and the ocean islands.

17897.text: ¶And he’ll raise that rallying banner high, visible to all nations,/_gather in all the scattered exiles of Israel,/Pull in all the dispersed refugees of Judah/_from the four winds and the seven seas.

17898.text: /The jealousy of Ephraim will dissolve,/_the hostility of Judah will vanish—/Ephraim no longer the jealous rival of Judah,/_Judah no longer the hostile rival of Ephraim!

17899.text: /Blood brothers united, they’ll pounce on the Philistines in the west,/_join forces to plunder the people in the east./They’ll attack Edom and Moab./_The Ammonites will fall into line.

17900.text: /God will once again dry up Egypt’s Red Sea,/_making for an easy crossing./He’ll send a blistering wind/_down on the great River Euphrates,/Reduce it to seven mere trickles./_None even need get their feet wet!

17901.text: /In the end there’ll be a highway all the way from Assyria,/_easy traveling for what’s left of God’s people—/A highway just like the one Israel had/_when he marched up out of Egypt.

17902.text: §¶And you will say in that day,/_“I thank you, God./You were angry/_but your anger wasn’t forever./You withdrew your anger/_and moved in and comforted me.

17903.text: ¶“Yes, indeed—God is my salvation./_I trust, I won’t be afraid./God—yes God!—is my strength and song,/_best of all, my salvation!”

17904.text: ¶Joyfully you’ll pull up buckets of water/_from the wells of salvation.

17905.text: /And as you do it, you’ll say,/_“Give thanks to God./Call out his name./_Ask him anything!/Shout to the nations, tell them what he’s done,/_spread the news of his great reputation!

17906.text: ¶“Sing praise‐songs to God. He’s done it all!/_Let the whole earth know what he’s done!

17907.text: /Raise the roof! Sing your hearts out, O Zion!/_The Greatest lives among you: The Holy of Israel.”

17908.text: §¶The Message on Babylon. Isaiah son of Amoz saw it:

17909.text: ¶“Run up a flag on an open hill.¶Yell loud. Get their attention./Wave them into formation./_Direct them to the nerve center of power.

17910.text: /I’ve taken charge of my special forces,/_called up my crack troops./They’re bursting with pride and passion/_to carry out my angry judgment.”

17911.text: ¶Thunder rolls off the mountains/_like a mob huge and noisy—/Thunder of kingdoms in an uproar,/_nations assembling for war./God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies is calling/_his army into battle formation.

17912.text: /They come from far‐off countries,/_they pour in across the horizon./It’s God on the move with the weapons of his wrath,/_ready to destroy the whole country.

17913.text: ¶Wail! God’s Day of Judgment is near—

17914.text: /_an avalanche crashing down from the Strong God!

17915.text: /Everyone paralyzed in the panic,/_hysterical and unstrung,/Doubled up in pain/_like a woman giving birth to a baby./Horrified—everyone they see/_is like a face out of a nightmare.

17916.text: ¶“Watch now. God’s Judgment Day comes./_Cruel it is, a day of wrath and anger,/A day to waste the earth/_and clean out all the sinners.

17917.text: /The stars in the sky, the great parade of constellations,/_will be nothing but black holes./The sun will come up as a black disk,/_and the moon a blank nothing.

17918.text: /I’ll put a full stop to the evil on earth,/_terminate the dark acts of the wicked./I’ll gag all braggarts and boasters—not a peep anymore from them—/_and trip strutting tyrants, leave them flat on their faces./Proud humanity will disappear from the earth.

17919.text: /_I’ll make mortals rarer than hens’ teeth.

17920.text: /And yes, I’ll even make the sky shake,/_and the earth quake to its roots/Under the wrath of God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies,/_the Judgment Day of his raging anger.

17921.text: /Like a hunted white‐tailed deer,/_like lost sheep with no shepherd,/People will huddle with a few of their own kind,/_run off to some makeshift shelter.

17922.text: /But tough luck to stragglers—they’ll be killed on the spot,

17923.text: /_throats cut, bellies ripped open,/Babies smashed on the rocks/_while mothers and fathers watch,/Houses looted,/_wives raped.

17924.text: ¶“And now watch this:/_Against Babylon, I’m inciting the Medes,/A ruthless bunch indifferent to bribes,/_the kind of brutality that no one can blunt.

17925.text: /They massacre the young,/_wantonly kick and kill even babies.

17926.text: /And Babylon, most glorious of all kingdoms,/_the pride and joy of Chaldeans,/Will end up smoking and stinking like Sodom,/_and, yes, like Gomorrah, when God had finished with them.

17927.text: /No one will live there anymore,/_generation after generation a ghost town./Not even Bedouins will pitch tents there./_Shepherds will give it a wide berth.

17928.text: /But strange and wild animals will like it just fine,/_filling the vacant houses with eerie night sounds./Skunks will make it their home,

17929.text: /_and unspeakable night hags will haunt it./Hyenas will curdle your blood with their laughing,/_and the howling of coyotes will give you the shivers.¶“Babylon is doomed./_It won’t be long now.”

17930.text: §¶But not so with Jacob. God will have compassion on Jacob. Once again he’ll choose Israel. He’ll establish them in their own country. Outsiders will be attracted and throw their lot in with Jacob.

17931.text: The nations among whom they lived will actually escort them back home, and then Israel will pay them back by making slaves of them, men and women alike, possessing them as slaves in God’s country, capturing those who had captured them, ruling over those who had abused them.

17932.text: ¶When God has given you time to recover from the abuse and trouble and harsh servitude that you had to endure, you can amuse yourselves by taking up this satire, a taunt against the king of Babylon:

17933.text: ¶Can you believe it? The tyrant is gone!/_The tyranny is over!

17934.text: /God has broken the rule of the wicked,/_the power of the bully‐rulers

17935.text: /That crushed many people./_A relentless rain of cruel outrage/Established a violent rule of anger/_rife with torture and persecution.

17936.text: ¶And now it’s over, the whole earth quietly at rest./_Burst into song!

17937.text: Make the rafters ring!/Ponderosa pine trees are happy,/_giant Lebanon cedars are relieved, saying,/“Since you’ve been cut down,/_there’s no one around to cut us down.”

17938.text: /And the underworld dead are all excited,/_preparing to welcome you when you come./Getting ready to greet you are the ghostly dead,/_all the famous names of earth./All the buried kings of the nations/_will stand up on their thrones

17939.text: /With well‐prepared speeches,/_royal invitations to death:/“Now you are as nothing as we are!/_Make yourselves at home with us dead folks!”

17940.text: ¶This is where your pomp and fine music led you, Babylon,/_to your underworld private chambers,/A king‐size mattress of maggots for repose/_and a quilt of crawling worms for warmth.

17941.text: ¶What a comedown this, O Babylon!/_Daystar! Son of Dawn!/Flat on your face in the underworld mud,/_you, famous for flattening nations!

17942.text: ¶You said to yourself,/_“I’ll climb to heaven./I’ll set my throne/_over the stars of God./I’ll run the assembly of angels/_that meets on sacred Mount Zaphon.

17943.text: /I’ll climb to the top of the clouds./_I’ll take over as King of the Universe!”

17944.text: ¶But you didn’t make it, did you?/_Instead of climbing up, you came down—/Down with the underground dead,/_down to the abyss of the Pit.

17945.text: /People will stare and muse:/_“Can this be the one/Who terrorized earth and its kingdoms,

17946.text: /_turned earth to a moonscape,/Wasted its cities,/_shut up his prisoners to a living death?”

17947.text: ¶Other kings get a decent burial,/_honored with eulogies and placed in a tomb.

17948.text: /But you’re dumped in a ditch unburied,/_like a stray dog or cat,/Covered with rotting bodies,/_murdered and indigent corpses./Your dead body desecrated, mutilated—

17949.text: /_no state funeral for you!/You’ve left your land in ruins,/_left a legacy of massacre./The progeny of your evil life/_will never be named. Oblivion!

17950.text: ¶Get a place ready to slaughter the sons of the wicked/_and wipe out their father’s line./Unthinkable that they should own a square foot of land/_or desecrate the face of the world with their cities!

17951.text: ¶“I will confront them”—Decree of God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies—“and strip Babylon of name and survivors, children and grandchildren.” God’s Decree.

17952.text: “I’ll make it a worthless swamp and give it as a prize to the hedgehog. And then I’ll bulldoze it out of existence.” Decree of God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies.

17953.text: §¶God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies speaks: ¶▼“Exactly as I planned,/_it will happen./Following my blueprints,/_it will take shape.

17954.text: /I will shatter the Assyrian who trespasses my land/_and stomp him into the dirt on my mountains./I will ban his taking and making of slaves/_and lift the weight of oppression from all shoulders.”

17955.text: /This is the plan,/_planned for the whole earth,/And this is the hand that will do it,/_reaching into every nation.

17956.text: /God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies has planned it./_Who could ever cancel such plans?/His is the hand that’s reached out./_Who could brush it aside?

17957.text: ¶In the year King Ahaz died, this Message came:¶Hold it, Philistines!

17958.text: It’s too soon to celebrate/_the defeat of your cruel oppressor./From the death throes of that snake a worse snake will come,/_and from that, one even worse.

17959.text: /The poor won’t have to worry./_The needy will escape the terror./But you Philistines will be plunged into famine,/_and those who don’t starve, God will kill.

17960.text: /Wail and howl, proud city!/_Fall prostrate in fear, Philistia!/On the northern horizon, smoke from burned cities,/_the wake of a brutal, disciplined destroyer.

17961.text: ¶What does one say to/_outsiders who ask questions?/Tell them, “God has established Zion./_Those in need and in trouble find refuge in her.”

17962.text: §¶A Message concerning Moab: ¶▼Village Ar of Moab is in ruins,/_destroyed in a night raid./Village Kir of Moab is in ruins,/_destroyed in a night raid.

17963.text: /Village Dibon climbs to its chapel in the hills,/_goes up to lament./Moab weeps and wails/_over Nebo and Medba./Every head is shaved bald,/_every beard shaved clean.

17964.text: /They pour into the streets wearing black,/_go up on the roofs, take to the town square,/Everyone in tears,/_everyone in grief.

17965.text: /Towns Heshbon and Elealeh cry long and loud./_The sound carries as far as Jahaz./Moab sobs, shaking in grief./_The soul of Moab trembles.

17966.text: ¶Oh, how I grieve for Moab!/_Refugees stream to Zoar/_and then on to Eglath‐shelishiyah./Up the slopes of Luhith they weep;/_on the road to Horonaim they cry their loss.

17967.text: /The springs of Nimrim are dried up—/_grass brown, buds stunted, nothing grows.

17968.text: /They leave, carrying all their possessions/_on their backs, everything they own,/Making their way as best they can/_across Willow Creek to safety.

17969.text: /Poignant cries reverberate/_all through Moab,/Gut‐wrenching sobs as far as Eglaim,/_heart‐racking sobs all the way to Beer‐elim.

17970.text: /The banks of the Dibon crest with blood,/_but God has worse in store for Dibon:/A lion—a lion to finish off the fugitives,/_to clean up whoever’s left in the land.

17971.text: §¶“Dispatch a gift of lambs,” says Moab,/_“to the leaders in Jerusalem—/Lambs from Sela sent across the desert/_to buy the goodwill of Jerusalem.

17972.text: /The towns and people of Moab/_are at a loss,/New‐hatched birds knocked from the nest,/_fluttering helplessly/At the banks of the Arnon River,/_unable to cross:

17973.text: /‘Tell us what to do,/_help us out!/Protect us,/_hide us!/Give the refugees from Moab/_sanctuary with you./Be a safe place for those on the run/_from the killing fields.’”

17974.text: ¶“When this is all over,” Judah answers,/_“the tyrant toppled,/The killing at an end,/_all signs of these cruelties long gone,

17975.text: /A new government of love will be established/_in the venerable David tradition./A Ruler you can depend upon/_will head this government,/A Ruler passionate for justice,/_a Ruler quick to set things right.”

17976.text: ¶We’ve heard—everyone’s heard!—of Moab’s pride,/_world‐famous for pride—/Arrogant, self‐important, insufferable,/_full of hot air./So now let Moab lament for a change,

17977.text: /_with antiphonal mock‐laments from the neighbors!/What a shame! How terrible!/_No more fine fruitcakes and Kir‐hareseth candies!/All those lush Heshbon fields dried up,/_the rich Sibmah vineyards withered!

17978.text: /Foreign thugs have crushed and torn out/_the famous grapevines/That once reached all the way to Jazer,/_right to the edge of the desert,/Ripped out the crops in every direction/_as far as the eye can see.

17979.text: /I’ll join the weeping. I’ll weep right along with Jazer,/_weep for the Sibmah vineyards./And yes, Heshbon and Elealeh,/_I’ll mingle my tears with your tears!/The joyful shouting at harvest is gone.

17980.text: /_Instead of song and celebration, dead silence./No more boisterous laughter in the orchards,/_no more hearty work songs in the vineyards./Instead of the bustle and sound of good work in the fields,/_silence—deathly and deadening silence.

17981.text: /My heartstrings throb like harp strings for Moab,/_my soul in sympathy for sad Kir‐heres.

17982.text: /When Moab trudges to the shrine to pray,/_he wastes both time and energy./Going to the sanctuary and praying for relief/_is useless. Nothing ever happens.

17983.text: ¶This is God’s earlier Message on Moab.

17984.text: God’s updated Message is, “In three years, no longer than the term of an enlisted soldier, Moab’s impressive presence will be gone, that splendid hot‐air balloon will be punctured, and instead of a vigorous population, just a few shuffling bums cadging handouts.”

17985.text: §¶A Message concerning Damascus: ¶▼“Watch this: Damascus undone as a city,/_a pile of dust and rubble!

17986.text: /Her towns emptied of people./_The sheep and goats will move in/And take over the towns/_as if they owned them—which they will!

17987.text: /Not a sign of a fort is left in Ephraim,/_not a trace of government left in Damascus./What’s left of Aram?/_The same as what’s left of Israel—not much.”/_Decree of God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies.

17988.text: §¶“The Day is coming when Jacob’s robust splendor goes pale/_and his well‐fed body turns skinny.

17989.text: /The country will be left empty, picked clean/_as a field harvested by field hands./She’ll be like a few stalks of barley left standing/_in the lush Valley of Rephaim after harvest,

17990.text: /Or like the couple of ripe olives overlooked/_in the top of the olive tree,/Or the four or five apples/_that the pickers couldn’t reach in the orchard.”/_Decree of the God of Israel.

17991.text: ¶Yes, the Day is coming when people will notice The One Who Made Them, take a long hard look at The Holy of Israel.

17992.text: They’ll lose interest in all the stuff they’ve made—altars and monuments and rituals, their homemade, handmade religion—however impressive it is.

17993.text: ¶And yes, the Day is coming when their fortress cities will be abandoned—the very same cities that the Hivites and Amorites abandoned when Israel invaded! And the country will be empty, desolate.

17994.text: §¶And why? Because you have forgotten God‐Your‐Salvation,/_not remembered your Rock‐of‐Refuge./And so, even though you are very religious,/_planting all sorts of bushes and herbs and trees/_to honor and influence your fertility gods,

17995.text: /And even though you make them grow so well,/_bursting with buds and sprouts and blossoms,/Nothing will come of them. Instead of a harvest/_you’ll get nothing but grief and pain, pain, pain.

17996.text: ¶Oh my! Thunder! A thundering herd of people!/_Thunder like the crashing of ocean waves!/Nations roaring, roaring,/_like the roar of a massive waterfall,

17997.text: /Roaring like a deafening Niagara!/_But God will silence them with a word,/And then he’ll blow them away like dead leaves off a tree,/_like down from a thistle.

17998.text: ¶At bedtime, terror fills the air./_By morning it’s gone—not a sign of it anywhere!/This is what happens to those who would ruin us,/_this is the fate of those out to get us.

17999.text: §¶Doom to the land of flies and mosquitoes/_beyond the Ethiopian rivers,

18000.text: /Shipping emissaries all over the world,/_down rivers and across seas.¶Go, swift messengers,/_go to this people tall and handsome,/This people held in respect everywhere,/_this people mighty and merciless,/_from the land crisscrossed with rivers.

18001.text: ¶Everybody everywhere,/_all earth‐dwellers:/When you see a flag flying on the mountain, look!/_When you hear the trumpet blown, listen!

18002.text: ¶For here’s what God told me:¶“I’m not going to say anything,/_but simply look on from where I live,/Quiet as warmth that comes from the sun,/_silent as dew during harvest.”

18003.text: /And then, just before harvest, after the blossom/_has turned into a maturing grape,/He’ll step in and prune back the new shoots,/_ruthlessly hack off all the growing branches.

18004.text: /He’ll leave them piled on the ground/_for birds and animals to feed on—/Fodder for the summering birds,/_fodder for the wintering animals.

18005.text: ¶Then tribute will be brought to God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies,/_brought from this people tall and handsome,/This people once held in respect everywhere,/_this people once mighty and merciless,/From the land crisscrossed with rivers,/_to Mount Zion, God’s place.

18006.text: §¶A Message concerning Egypt: ¶▼Watch this! God riding on a fast‐moving cloud,/_moving in on Egypt!/The god‐idols of Egypt shudder and shake,/_Egyptians paralyzed by panic.

18007.text: ¶God says, “I’ll make Egyptian fight Egyptian,/_brother fight brother, neighbor fight neighbor,/City fight city, kingdom fight kingdom—

18008.text: /_anarchy and chaos and killing!/I’ll knock the wind out of the Egyptians./_They won’t know coming from going./They’ll go to their god‐idols for answers;/_they’ll conjure ghosts and hold séances, desperate for answers.

18009.text: /But I’ll turn the Egyptians/_over to a tyrant most cruel./I’ll put them under the rule of a mean, merciless king.”/_Decree of the Master, God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies.

18010.text: ¶The River Nile will dry up,/_the riverbed baked dry in the sun.

18011.text: /The canals will become stagnant and stink,/_every stream touching the Nile dry up./River vegetation will rot away

18012.text: /_the banks of the Nile‐baked clay,/The riverbed hard and smooth,/_river grasses dried up and gone with the wind.

18013.text: /Fishermen will complain/_that the fishing’s been ruined.

18014.text: /Textile workers will be out of work, all weavers/_and workers in linen and cotton and wool/Dispirited, depressed in their forced idleness—

18015.text: /_everyone who works for a living, jobless.

18016.text: ¶The princes of Zoan are fools,/_the advisors of Pharaoh stupid./How could any of you dare tell Pharaoh,/_“Trust me: I’m wise. I know what’s going on./_Why, I’m descended from the old wisdom of Egypt”?

18017.text: /There’s not a wise man or woman left in the country./_If there were, one of them would tell you/_what God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies has in mind for Egypt.

18018.text: /As it is, the princes of Zoan are all fools/_and the princes of Memphis, dunces./The honored pillars of your society/_have led Egypt into detours and dead ends.

18019.text: /God has scrambled their brains,/_Egypt’s become a falling‐down‐in‐his‐own‐vomit drunk.

18020.text: /Egypt’s hopeless, past helping,/_a senile, doddering old fool.

18021.text: ¶On that Day, Egyptians will be like hysterical schoolgirls, screaming at the first hint of action from God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies.

18022.text: Little Judah will strike terror in Egyptians! Say “Judah” to an Egyptian and see panic. The word triggers fear of the God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies’ plan against Egypt.

18023.text: ¶On that Day, more than one city in Egypt will learn to speak the language of faith and promise to follow God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies. One of these cities will be honored with the title “City of the Sun.”

18024.text: ¶On that Day, there will be a place of worship to God in the center of Egypt and a monument to God at its border.

18025.text: It will show how the God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies has helped the Egyptians. When they cry out in prayer to God because of oppressors, he’ll send them help, a savior who will keep them safe and take care of them.

18026.text: God will openly show himself to the Egyptians and they’ll get to know him on that Day. They’ll worship him seriously with sacrifices and burnt offerings. They’ll make vows and keep them.

18027.text: God will wound Egypt, first hit and then heal. Egypt will come back to God, and God will listen to their prayers and heal them, heal them from head to toe.

18028.text: ¶On that Day, there will be a highway all the way from Egypt to Assyria: Assyrians will have free range in Egypt and Egyptians in Assyria. No longer rivals, they’ll worship together, Egyptians and Assyrians!

18029.text: ¶On that Day, Israel will take its place alongside Egypt and Assyria, sharing the blessing from the center.

18030.text: God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies, who blessed Israel, will generously bless them all: “Blessed be Egypt, my people! . . . Blessed be Assyria, work of my hands! . . . Blessed be Israel, my heritage!”

18031.text: §¶In the year the field commander, sent by King Sargon of Assyria, came to Ashdod and fought and took it,

18032.text: God told Isaiah son of Amoz, “Go, take off your clothes and sandals,” and Isaiah did it, going about naked and barefooted.

18033.text: ¶Then God said, “Just as my servant Isaiah has walked around town naked and barefooted for three years as a warning sign to Egypt and Ethiopia, so the king of Assyria is going to come and take the Egyptians as captives and the Ethiopians as exiles.

18034.text: He’ll take young and old alike and march them out of there naked and barefooted, exposed to mockery and jeers—the bared buttocks of Egypt on parade!

18035.text: Everyone who has put hope in Ethiopia and expected help from Egypt will be thrown into confusion.

18036.text: Everyone who lives along this coast will say, ‘Look at them! Naked and barefooted, shuffling off to exile! And we thought they were our best hope, that they’d rescue us from the king of Assyria. Now what’s going to happen to us? How are we going to get out of this?’”

18037.text: §¶A Message concerning the desert at the sea: ¶▼As tempests drive through the Negev Desert,/_coming out of the desert, that terror‐filled place,

18038.text: /A hard vision is given me:/_The betrayer betrayed, the plunderer plundered./Attack, Elam!/_Lay siege, Media!/Persians, attack!/_Attack, Babylon!/I’ll put an end to/_all the moaning and groaning.

18039.text: /Because of this news I’m doubled up in pain,/_writhing in pain like a woman having a baby,/Baffled by what I hear,/_undone by what I see.

18040.text: /Absolutely stunned,/_horror‐stricken,/I had hoped for a relaxed evening,/_but it has turned into a nightmare.

18041.text: ¶The banquet is spread,/_the guests reclining in luxurious ease,/Eating and drinking, having a good time,/_and then, “To arms, princes! The fight is on!”

18042.text: ¶The Master told me, “Go, post a lookout./_Have him report whatever he spots.

18043.text: /When he sees horses and wagons in battle formation,/_lines of donkeys and columns of camels,/Tell him to keep his ear to the ground,/_note every whisper, every rumor.”

18044.text: /Just then, the lookout shouted,/_“I’m at my post, Master,/Sticking to my post day after day/_and all through the night!

18045.text: /I watched them come,/_the horses and wagons in battle formation./I heard them call out the war news in headlines:/_‘Babylon fallen! Fallen!/And all its precious god‐idols/_smashed to pieces on the ground.’”

18046.text: ¶Dear Israel, you’ve been through a lot,/_you’ve been put through the mill./The good news I get from God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies,/_the God of Israel, I now pass on to you.

18047.text: ¶A Message concerning Edom: ¶▼A voice calls to me/_from the Seir mountains in Edom,/“Night watchman! How long till daybreak?/_How long will this night last?”

18048.text: /The night watchman calls back,/_“Morning’s coming,/But for now it’s still night./_If you ask me again, I’ll give the same answer.”

18049.text: ¶A Message concerning Arabia: ¶▼You’ll have to camp out in the desert badlands,/_you caravans of Dedanites.

18050.text: /Haul water to the thirsty,/_greet fugitives with bread.

18051.text: /Show your desert hospitality,/_you who live in Tema./The desert’s swarming with refugees/_escaping the horrors of war.

18052.text: ¶The Master told me, “Hang on. Within one year—I’ll sign a contract on it!—the arrogant brutality of Kedar, those hooligans of the desert, will be over, nothing much left of the Kedar toughs.”

18053.text: The God of Israel says so.

18054.text: §¶A Message concerning the Valley of Vision: ¶▼What’s going on here anyway?

18055.text: /_All this partying and noisemaking,/Shouting and cheering in the streets,/_the city noisy with celebrations!/You have no brave soldiers to honor,/_no combat heroes to be proud of.

18056.text: /Your leaders were all cowards,/_captured without even lifting a sword,/A country of cowards/_captured escaping the battle.

18057.text: §¶In the midst of the shouting, I said, “Let me alone./_Let me grieve by myself./Don’t tell me it’s going to be all right./_These people are doomed. It’s not all right.”

18058.text: /For the Master, God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies,/_is bringing a day noisy with mobs of people,/Jostling and stampeding in the Valley of Vision,/_knocking down walls/_and hollering to the mountains, “Attack! Attack!”

18059.text: /Old enemies Elam and Kir arrive armed to the teeth—/_weapons and chariots and cavalry.

18060.text: /Your fine valleys are noisy with war,/_chariots and cavalry charging this way and that./_God has left Judah exposed and defenseless.

18061.text: ¶You assessed your defenses that Day, inspected your arsenal of weapons in the Forest Armory.

18062.text: You found the weak places in the city walls that needed repair. You secured the water supply at the Lower Pool.

18063.text: You took an inventory of the houses in Jerusalem and tore down some to get bricks to fortify the city wall.

18064.text: You built a large cistern to ensure plenty of water.¶You looked and looked and looked, but you never looked to him who gave you this city, never once consulted the One who has long had plans for this city.

18065.text: ¶The Master, God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies,/_called out on that Day,/Called for a day of repentant tears,/_called you to dress in somber clothes of mourning.

18066.text: /But what do you do? You throw a party!/_Eating and drinking and dancing in the streets!/You barbecue bulls and sheep, and throw a huge feast—/_slabs of meat, kegs of beer./“Seize the day! Eat and drink!/_Tomorrow we die!”

18067.text: ¶God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies whispered to me his verdict on this frivolity: “You’ll pay for this outrage until the day you die.” The Master, God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies, says so.

18068.text: §¶The Master, God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies, spoke: “Come. Go to this steward, Shebna, who is in charge of all the king’s affairs, and tell him:

18069.text: What’s going on here? You’re an outsider here and yet you act like you own the place, make a big, fancy tomb for yourself where everyone can see it, making sure everyone will think you’re important.

18070.text: God is about to sack you, to throw you to the dogs.

18071.text: He’ll grab you by the hair, swing you round and round dizzyingly, and then let you go, sailing through the air like a ball, until you’re out of sight. Where you’ll land, nobody knows. And there you’ll die, and all the stuff you’ve collected heaped on your grave. You’ve disgraced your master’s house!

18073.text: ¶“On that Day I’ll replace Shebna. I will call my servant Eliakim son of Hilkiah.

18074.text: I’ll dress him in your robe. I’ll put your belt on him. I’ll give him your authority. He’ll be a father‐leader to Jerusalem and the government of Judah.

18075.text: I’ll give him the key of the Davidic heritage. He’ll have the run of the place—open any door and keep it open, lock any door and keep it locked.

18076.text: I’ll pound him like a nail into a solid wall. He’ll secure the Davidic tradition.

18077.text: Everything will hang on him—not only the fate of Davidic descendants but also the detailed daily operations of the house, including cups and cutlery.

18078.text: ¶“And then the Day will come,” says God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies, “when that nail will come loose and fall out, break loose from that solid wall—and everything hanging on it will go with it.” That’s what will happen. God says so.

18079.text: §¶Wail, ships of Tarshish,/_your strong seaports all in ruins!/When the ships returned from Cyprus,/_they saw the destruction.

18080.text: /Hold your tongue, you who live on the seacoast,/_merchants of Sidon./Your people sailed the deep seas,/_buying and selling,

18081.text: /Making money on wheat from Shihor,/_grown along the Nile—/_multinational broker in grains!

18082.text: /Hang your head in shame, Sidon. The Sea speaks up,/_the powerhouse of the ocean says,/“I’ve never had labor pains, never had a baby,/_never reared children to adulthood,/Never gave life, never worked with life./_It was all numbers, dead numbers, profit and loss.”

18083.text: ¶When Egypt gets the report on Tyre,/_what wailing! what wringing of hands!

18084.text: §¶Visit Tarshish, you who live on the seacoast.

18085.text: /_Take a good, long look and wail—yes, cry buckets of tears!/Is this the city you remember as energetic and alive,/_bustling with activity, this historic old city,/Expanding throughout the globe,/_buying and selling all over the world?

18086.text: /And who is behind the collapse of Tyre,/_the Tyre that controlled the world markets?/Tyre’s merchants were the business tycoons./_Tyre’s traders called all the shots.

18087.text: /God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies ordered the crash/_to show the sordid backside of pride/_and puncture the inflated reputations.

18088.text: /Sail for home, O ships of Tarshish./_There are no docks left in this harbor.

18089.text: /God reached out to the sea and sea traders,/_threw the sea kingdoms into turmoil./God ordered the destruction/_of the seacoast cities, the centers of commerce.

18090.text: /God said, “There’s nothing left here to be proud of,/_bankrupt and bereft Sidon./Do you want to make a new start in Cyprus?/_Don’t count on it. Nothing there will work out for you either.”

18091.text: ¶Look at what happened to Babylon: There’s nothing left of it. Assyria turned it into a desert, into a refuge for wild dogs and stray cats. They brought in their big siege engines, tore down the buildings, and left nothing behind but rubble.

18092.text: ¶Wail, ships of Tarshish,/_your strong seaports all in ruins!

18093.text: ¶For the next seventy years, a king’s lifetime, Tyre will be forgotten. At the end of the seventy years, Tyre will stage a comeback, but it will be the comeback of a worn‐out whore, as in the song:

18094.text: ¶“Take a harp, circle the city,/_unremembered whore./Sing your old songs, your many old songs./_Maybe someone will remember.”

18095.text: ¶At the end of the seventy years, God will look in on Tyre. She’ll go back to her old whoring trade, selling herself to the highest bidder, doing anything with anyone—promiscuous with all the kingdoms of earth—for a fee.

18096.text: But everything she gets, all the money she takes in, will be turned over to God. It will not be put in banks. Her profits will be put to the use of God‐Aware, God‐Serving‐People, providing plenty of food and the best of clothing.

18097.text: §¶Danger ahead! God’s about to ravish the earth/_and leave it in ruins,/Rip everything out by the roots/_and send everyone scurrying:

18098.text: /_priests and laypeople alike,/_owners and workers alike,/_celebrities and nobodies alike,/_buyers and sellers alike,/_bankers and beggars alike,/_the haves and have‐nots alike.

18099.text: /The landscape will be a moonscape,/_totally wasted./And why? Because God says so./_He’s issued the orders.

18100.text: ¶The earth turns gaunt and gray,/_the world silent and sad,/_sky and land lifeless, colorless.

18101.text: §¶Earth is polluted by its very own people,/_who have broken its laws,/Disrupted its order,/_violated the sacred and eternal covenant.

18102.text: /Therefore a curse, like a cancer,/_ravages the earth./Its people pay the price of their sacrilege./_They dwindle away, dying out one by one.

18103.text: /No more wine, no more vineyards,/_no more songs or singers.

18104.text: /The laughter of castanets is gone,/_the shouts of celebrants, gone,/_the laughter of fiddles, gone.

18105.text: /No more parties with toasts of champagne./_Serious drinkers gag on their drinks.

18106.text: /The chaotic cities are unlivable. Anarchy reigns./_Every house is boarded up, condemned.

18107.text: /People riot in the streets for wine,/_but the good times are gone forever—/_no more joy for this old world.

18108.text: /The city is dead and deserted,/_bulldozed into piles of rubble.

18109.text: /That’s the way it will be on this earth./_This is the fate of all nations:/An olive tree shaken clean of its olives,/_a grapevine picked clean of its grapes.

18110.text: ¶But there are some who will break into glad song./_Out of the west they’ll shout of God’s majesty./Yes, from the east God’s glory will ascend.

18111.text: /_Every island of the sea/Will broadcast God’s fame,/_the fame of the God of Israel.

18112.text: /From the four winds and the seven seas we hear the singing:/_“All praise to the Righteous One!” ¶But I said, “That’s all well and good for somebody,/_but all I can see is doom, doom, and more doom.”/All of them at one another’s throats,/_yes, all of them at one another’s throats.

18113.text: /Terror and pits and booby traps/_are everywhere, whoever you are.

18114.text: /If you run from the terror,/_you’ll fall into the pit./If you climb out of the pit,/_you’ll get caught in the trap./Chaos pours out of the skies./_The foundations of earth are crumbling.

18115.text: /Earth is smashed to pieces,/_earth is ripped to shreds,/_earth is wobbling out of control,

18116.text: /Earth staggers like a drunk,/_sways like a shack in a high wind./Its piled‐up sins are too much for it./_It collapses and won’t get up again.

18117.text: ¶That’s when God will call on the carpet/_rebel powers in the skies and/Rebel kings on earth.

18118.text: /_They’ll be rounded up like prisoners in a jail,/Corralled and locked up in a jail,/_and then sentenced and put to hard labor.

18119.text: /Shamefaced moon will cower, humiliated,/_red‐faced sun will skulk, disgraced,/Because God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies will take over,/_ruling from Mount Zion and Jerusalem,/Splendid and glorious/_before all his leaders.

18120.text: §¶God, you are my God./_I celebrate you. I praise you./You’ve done your share of miracle‐wonders,/_well‐thought‐out plans, solid and sure.

18121.text: /Here you’ve reduced the city to rubble,/_the strong city to a pile of stones./The enemy Big City is a non‐city,/_never to be a city again.

18122.text: /Superpowers will see it and honor you,/_brutal oppressors bow in worshipful reverence.

18123.text: /They’ll see that you take care of the poor,/_that you take care of poor people in trouble,/Provide a warm, dry place in bad weather,/_provide a cool place when it’s hot./Brutal oppressors are like a winter blizzard

18124.text: /_and vicious foreigners like high noon in the desert./But you, shelter from the storm and shade from the sun,/_shut the mouths of the big‐mouthed bullies.

18125.text: ¶But here on this mountain, God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies/_will throw a feast for all the people of the world,/A feast of the finest foods, a feast with vintage wines,/_a feast of seven courses, a feast lavish with gourmet desserts.

18126.text: /And here on this mountain, God will banish/_the pall of doom hanging over all peoples,/The shadow of doom darkening all nations.

18127.text: /_Yes, he’ll banish death forever./And God will wipe the tears from every face./_He’ll remove every sign of disgrace/From his people, wherever they are./_Yes! God says so!

18128.text: ¶Also at that time, people will say,/_“Look at what’s happened! This is our God!/We waited for him and he showed up and saved us!/_This God, the one we waited for!/Let’s celebrate, sing the joys of his salvation.

18129.text: /_God’s hand rests on this mountain!”  ¶As for the Moabites, they’ll be treated like refuse,/_waste shoveled into a cesspool.

18130.text: /Thrash away as they will,/_like swimmers trying to stay afloat,/They’ll sink in the sewage./_Their pride will pull them under.

18131.text: /Their famous fortifications will crumble to nothing,/_those mighty walls reduced to dust.

18132.text: §¶At that time, this song/_will be sung in the country of Judah:/We have a strong city, Salvation City,/_built and fortified with salvation.

18133.text: /Throw wide the gates/_so good and true people can enter.

18134.text: /People with their minds set on you,/_you keep completely whole,/Steady on their feet,/_because they keep at it and don’t quit.

18135.text: /Depend on God and keep at it/_because in the Lord God you have a sure thing.

18136.text: /Those who lived high and mighty/_he knocked off their high horse./He used the city built on the hill/_as fill for the marshes.

18137.text: /All the exploited and outcast peoples/_build their lives on the reclaimed land.

18138.text: ¶The path of right‐living people is level./_The Leveler evens the road for the right‐living.

18139.text: /We’re in no hurry, God. We’re content to linger/_in the path sign‐posted with your decisions./Who you are and what you’ve done/_are all we’ll ever want.

18140.text: /Through the night my soul longs for you./_Deep from within me my spirit reaches out to you./When your decisions are on public display,/_everyone learns how to live right.

18141.text: /If the wicked are shown grace,/_they don’t seem to get it./In the land of right living, they persist in wrong living,/_blind to the splendor of God.

18142.text: ¶You hold your hand up high, God,/_but they don’t see it./Open their eyes to what you do,/_to see your zealous love for your people./Shame them. Light a fire under them./_Get the attention of these enemies of yours.

18143.text: /God, order a peaceful and whole life for us/_because everything we’ve done, you’ve done for us.

18144.text: /O God, our God, we’ve had other masters rule us,/_but you’re the only Master we’ve ever known.

18145.text: /The dead don’t talk,/_ghosts don’t walk,/Because you’ve said, “Enough—that’s all for you,”/_and wiped them off the books.

18146.text: /But the living you make larger than life./_The more life you give, the more glory you display,/_and stretch the borders to accommodate more living!

18147.text: ¶O God, they begged you for help when they were in trouble,/_when your discipline was so heavy/_they could barely whisper a prayer.

18148.text: /Like a woman having a baby,/_writhing in distress, screaming her pain/_as the baby is being born,/That’s how we were because of you, O God.

18149.text: /_We were pregnant full‐term./We writhed in labor but bore no baby./_We gave birth to wind./Nothing came of our labor./_We produced nothing living./_We couldn’t save the world.

18150.text: ¶But friends, your dead will live,/_your corpses will get to their feet./All you dead and buried,/_wake up! Sing!/Your dew is morning dew/_catching the first rays of sun,/The earth bursting with life,/_giving birth to the dead.

18151.text: ¶Come, my people, go home/_and shut yourselves in./Go into seclusion for a while/_until the punishing wrath is past,

18152.text: /Because God is sure to come from his place/_to punish the wrong of the people on earth./Earth itself will point out the bloodstains;/_it will show where the murdered have been hidden away.

18153.text: §¶At that time God will unsheathe his sword,/_his merciless, massive, mighty sword./He’ll punish the serpent Leviathan as it flees,/_the serpent Leviathan thrashing in flight./He’ll kill that old dragon/_that lives in the sea.

18154.text: ¶“At that same time, a fine vineyard will appear./_There’s something to sing about!

18155.text: /I, God, tend it./_I keep it well‐watered./I keep careful watch over it/_so that no one can damage it.

18156.text: /I’m not angry. I care./_Even if it gives me thistles and thornbushes,/I’ll just pull them out/_and burn them up.

18157.text: /Let that vine cling to me for safety,/_let it find a good and whole life with me,/_let it hold on for a good and whole life.”

18158.text: ¶The days are coming when Jacob/_shall put down roots,/Israel blossom and grow fresh branches,/_and fill the world with its fruit.

18159.text: ¶Has God knocked them to the ground/_as he knocked down those who hit them? Oh, no./Were they killed/_as their killers were killed?

18160.text: Again, no./He was hard on them all right. The exile was a harsh sentence./_He blew them away on a fierce blast of wind.

18161.text: /But the good news is that through this experience/_Jacob’s guilt was taken away./_The evidence that his sin is removed will be this:/He will tear down the alien altars,/_take them apart stone by stone,/And then crush the stones into gravel/_and clean out all the sex‐and‐religion shrines.

18162.text: /For there’s nothing left of that pretentious grandeur./_Nobody lives there anymore. It’s unlivable./But animals do just fine,/_browsing and bedding down.

18163.text: /And it’s not a bad place to get firewood./_Dry twigs and dead branches are plentiful./It’s the leavings of a people with no sense of God./_So, the God who made them/Will have nothing to do with them./_He who formed them will turn his back on them.

18164.text: ¶At that time God will thresh/_from the River Euphrates to the Brook of Egypt,/And you, people of Israel,/_will be selected grain by grain.

18165.text: /At that same time a great trumpet will be blown,/_calling home the exiles from Assyria,/Welcoming home the refugees from Egypt/_to come and worship God on the holy mountain, Jerusalem.

18166.text: §¶Doom to the pretentious drunks of Ephraim,/_shabby and washed out and seedy—/Tipsy, sloppy‐fat, beer‐bellied parodies/_of a proud and handsome past.

18167.text: /Watch closely: God has someone picked out,/_someone tough and strong to flatten them./Like a hailstorm, like a hurricane, like a flash flood,/_one‐handed he’ll throw them to the ground.
