18168.text: /Samaria, the party hat on Israel’s head,/_will be knocked off with one blow.

18169.text: /It will disappear quicker than/_a piece of meat tossed to a dog.

18170.text: ¶At that time, God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies will be/_the beautiful crown on the head of what’s left of his people:

18171.text: /Energy and insights of justice to those who guide and decide,/_strength and prowess to those who guard and protect.

18172.text: ¶These also, the priest and prophet, stagger from drink,/_weaving, falling‐down drunks,/Besotted with wine and whiskey,/_can’t see straight, can’t talk sense.

18173.text: /Every table is covered with vomit./_They live in vomit.

18174.text: ¶“Is that so? And who do you think you are to teach us?/_Who are you to lord it over us?/We’re not babies in diapers

18175.text: /_to be talked down to by such as you—/‘Da, da, da, da,/_blah, blah, blah, blah./That’s a good little girl,/_that’s a good little boy.’”

18176.text: ¶But that’s exactly how you will be addressed./_God will speak to this people/In baby talk, one syllable at a time—/_and he’ll do it through foreign oppressors.

18177.text: /He said before, “This is the time and place to rest,/_to give rest to the weary./This is the place to lay down your burden.”/_But they won’t listen.

18178.text: ¶So God will start over with the simple basics/_and address them in baby talk, one syllable at a time—/“Da, da, da, da,/_blah, blah, blah, blah./That’s a good little girl,/_that’s a good little boy.”/And like toddlers, they will get up and fall down,/_get bruised and confused and lost.

18179.text: ¶Now listen to God’s Message, you scoffers,/_you who rule this people in Jerusalem.

18180.text: /You say, “We’ve taken out good life insurance./_We’ve hedged all our bets, covered all our bases./No disaster can touch us. We’ve thought of everything./_We’re advised by the experts. We’re set.”

18181.text: §¶But the Master, God, has something to say to this: ¶▼“Watch closely. I’m laying a foundation in Zion,/_a solid granite foundation, squared and true./And this is the meaning of the stone:/_a trusting life won’t topple.

18182.text: /I’ll make justice the measuring stick/_and righteousness the plumb line for the building./A hailstorm will knock down the shantytown of lies,/_and a flash flood will wash out the rubble.

18183.text: ¶“Then you’ll see that your precious life insurance policy/_wasn’t worth the paper it was written on./Your careful precautions against death/_were a pack of illusions and lies./When the disaster happens,/_you’ll be crushed by it.

18184.text: /Every time disaster comes, you’ll be in on it—/_disaster in the morning, disaster at night.”/Every report of disaster/_will send you cowering in terror.

18185.text: /There will be no place where you can rest,/_nothing to hide under.

18186.text: /God will rise to full stature,/_raging as he did long ago on Mount Perazim/And in the valley of Gibeon against the Philistines./_But this time it’s against you./Hard to believe, but true./_Not what you’d expect, but it’s coming.

18187.text: /Sober up, friends, and don’t scoff./_Scoffing will just make it worse./I’ve heard the orders issued for destruction, orders from/_God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies—ending up in an international disaster.

18188.text: ¶Listen to me now./_Give me your closest attention.

18189.text: /Do farmers plow and plow and do nothing but plow?/_Or harrow and harrow and do nothing but harrow?

18190.text: /After they’ve prepared the ground, don’t they plant?/_Don’t they scatter dill and spread cumin,/Plant wheat and barley in the fields/_and raspberries along the borders?/They know exactly what to do and when to do it.

18192.text: ¶And at the harvest, the delicate herbs and spices,/_the dill and cumin, are treated delicately.

18193.text: /On the other hand, wheat is threshed and milled, but still not endlessly./_The farmer knows how to treat each kind of grain.

18194.text: /He’s learned it all from God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies,/_who knows everything about when and how and where.

18195.text: §¶Doom, Ariel, Ariel,/_the city where David set camp!/Let the years add up,/_let the festivals run their cycles,

18196.text: /But I’m not letting up on Jerusalem./_The moaning and groaning will continue./_Jerusalem to me is an Ariel.

18197.text: /Like David, I’ll set up camp against you./_I’ll set siege, build towers,/_bring in siege engines, build siege ramps.

18198.text: /Driven into the ground, you’ll speak,/_you’ll mumble words from the dirt—/Your voice from the ground, like the muttering of a ghost./_Your speech will whisper from the dust.

18199.text: ¶But it will be your enemies who are beaten to dust,/_the mob of tyrants who will be blown away like chaff./Because, surprise, as if out of nowhere,

18200.text: /_a visit from God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies,/With thunderclaps, earthquakes, and earsplitting noise,/_backed up by hurricanes, tornadoes, and lightning strikes,

18201.text: /And the mob of enemies at war with Ariel,/_all who trouble and hassle and torment her,/_will turn out to be a bad dream, a nightmare.

18202.text: /Like a hungry man dreaming he’s eating steak/_and wakes up hungry as ever,/Like a thirsty woman dreaming she’s drinking iced tea/_and wakes up thirsty as ever,/So that mob of nations at war against Mount Zion

18203.text: /_will wake up and find they haven’t shot an arrow,/_haven’t killed a single soul.  ¶Drug yourselves so you feel nothing./_Blind yourselves so you see nothing./Get drunk, but not on wine./_Black out, but not from whiskey.

18204.text: /For God has rocked you into a deep, deep sleep,/_put the discerning prophets to sleep,/_put the farsighted seers to sleep.

18205.text: §¶What you’ve been shown here is somewhat like a letter in a sealed envelope. If you give it to someone who can read and tell her, “Read this,” she’ll say, “I can’t. The envelope is sealed.”

18206.text: And if you give it to someone who can’t read and tell him, “Read this,” he’ll say, “I can’t read.”

18207.text: ¶The Master said: ¶▼“These people make a big show of saying the right thing,/_but their hearts aren’t in it./Because they act like they’re worshiping me/_but don’t mean it,

18208.text: /I’m going to step in and shock them awake,/_astonish them, stand them on their ears./The wise ones who had it all figured out/_will be exposed as fools./The smart people who thought they knew everything/_will turn out to know nothing.”

18209.text: ¶Doom to you! You pretend to have the inside track./_You shut God out and work behind the scenes,/Plotting the future as if you knew everything,/_acting mysterious, never showing your hand.

18210.text: /You have everything backward!/_You treat the potter as a lump of clay./Does a book say to its author,/_“He didn’t write a word of me”?/Does a meal say to the woman who cooked it,/_“She had nothing to do with this”?

18211.text: ¶And then before you know it,/_and without you having anything to do with it,/Wasted Lebanon will be transformed into lush gardens,/_and Mount Carmel reforested.

18212.text: /At that time the deaf will hear/_word‐for‐word what’s been written./After a lifetime in the dark,/_the blind will see.

18213.text: /The castoffs of society will be laughing and dancing in God,/_the down‐and‐outs shouting praise to The Holy of Israel.

18214.text: /For there’ll be no more gangs on the street./_Cynical scoffers will be an extinct species./Those who never missed a chance to hurt or demean/_will never be heard of again:

18215.text: /Gone the people who corrupted the courts,/_gone the people who cheated the poor,/_gone the people who victimized the innocent.

18216.text: ¶And finally this, God’s Message for the family of Jacob,/_the same God who redeemed Abraham:/“No longer will Jacob hang his head in shame,/_no longer grow gaunt and pale with waiting.

18217.text: /For he’s going to see his children,/_my personal gift to him—lots of children./And these children will honor me/_by living holy lives./In holy worship they’ll honor the Holy One of Jacob/_and stand in holy awe of the God of Israel.

18218.text: /Those who got off‐track will get back on‐track,/_and complainers and whiners learn gratitude.”

18219.text: §¶“Doom, rebel children!”/_God’s Decree./“You make plans, but not mine./_You make deals, but not in my Spirit./You pile sin on sin,

18220.text: /_one sin on top of another,/Going off to Egypt/_without so much as asking me,/Running off to Pharaoh for protection,/_expecting to hide out in Egypt.

18221.text: /Well, some protection Pharaoh will be!/_Some hideout, Egypt!/They look big and important, true,/_with officials strategically established in

18222.text: /Zoan in the north and Hanes in the south,/_but there’s nothing to them.

18223.text: /Anyone stupid enough to trust them/_will end up looking stupid—/All show, no substance,/_an embarrassing farce.”

18224.text: ¶And this note on the animals of the Negev/_encountered on the road to Egypt:/A most dangerous, treacherous route,/_menaced by lions and deadly snakes./And you’re going to lug all your stuff down there,/_your donkeys and camels loaded down with bribes,/Thinking you can buy protection/_from that hollow farce of a nation?

18225.text: /Egypt is all show, no substance./_My name for her is Toothless Dragon.

18226.text: §¶So, go now and write all this down./_Put it in a book/So that the record will be there

18227.text: /_to instruct the coming generations,/Because this is a rebel generation,/_a people who lie,/A people unwilling to listen/_to anything God tells them.

18228.text: /They tell their spiritual leaders,/_“Don’t bother us with irrelevancies.”/They tell their preachers,/_“Don’t waste our time on impracticalities./Tell us what makes us feel better.

18229.text: /_Don’t bore us with obsolete religion./That stuff means nothing to us./_Quit hounding us with The Holy of Israel.”

18230.text: ¶Therefore, The Holy of Israel says this:/_“Because you scorn this Message,/Preferring to live by injustice/_and shape your lives on lies,

18231.text: /This perverse way of life/_will be like a towering, badly built wall/That slowly, slowly tilts and shifts,/_and then one day, without warning, collapses—

18232.text: /Smashed to bits like a piece of pottery,/_smashed beyond recognition or repair,/Useless, a pile of debris/_to be swept up and thrown in the trash.”

18233.text: §¶God, the Master, The Holy of Israel,/_has this solemn counsel:/“Your salvation requires you to turn back to me/_and stop your silly efforts to save yourselves./Your strength will come from settling down/_in complete dependence on me—/The very thing/_you’ve been unwilling to do.

18234.text: /You’ve said, ‘Nothing doing! We’ll rush off on horseback!’/_You’ll rush off, all right! Just not far enough!/You’ve said, ‘We’ll ride off on fast horses!’/_Do you think your pursuers ride old nags?/Think again:

18235.text: A thousand of you will scatter before one attacker./_Before a mere five you’ll all run off./There’ll be nothing left of you—/_a flagpole on a hill with no flag,/_a signpost on a roadside with the sign torn off.”

18236.text: ¶But God’s not finished. He’s waiting around to be gracious to you./_He’s gathering strength to show mercy to you./God takes the time to do everything right—everything./_Those who wait around for him are the lucky ones.

18237.text: ¶Oh yes, people of Zion, citizens of Jerusalem, your time of tears is over. Cry for help and you’ll find it’s grace and more grace. The moment he hears, he’ll answer.

18238.text: Just as the Master kept you alive during the hard times, he’ll keep your teacher alive and present among you.

18239.text: Your teacher will be right there, local and on the job, urging you on whenever you wander left or right: “This is the right road. Walk down this road.”

18240.text: You’ll scrap your expensive and fashionable god‐images. You’ll throw them in the trash as so much garbage, saying, “Good riddance!”

18241.text: ¶God will provide rain for the seeds you sow. The grain that grows will be abundant. Your cattle will range far and wide.

18242.text: Oblivious to war and earthquake, the oxen and donkeys you use for hauling and plowing will be fed well

18243.text: near running brooks that flow freely from mountains and hills.

18244.text: Better yet, on the Day God heals his people of the wounds and bruises from the time of punishment, moonlight will flare into sunlight, and sunlight, like a whole week of sunshine at once, will flood the land.

18245.text: ¶Look, God’s on his way,/_and from a long way off!/Smoking with anger,/_immense as he comes into view,/Words steaming from his mouth,/_searing, indicting words!

18246.text: /A torrent of words, a flash flood of words/_sweeping everyone into the vortex of his words./He’ll shake down the nations in a sieve of destruction,/_herd them into a dead end.

18247.text: ¶But you will sing,/_sing through an all‐night holy feast!/Your hearts will burst with song,/_make music like the sound of flutes on parade,/En route to the mountain of God,/_on the way to the Rock of Israel.

18248.text: /God will sound out in grandiose thunder,/_display his hammering arm,/Furiously angry, showering sparks—/_cloudburst, storm, hail!

18249.text: /Oh yes, at God’s thunder/_Assyria will cower under the clubbing.

18250.text: /Every blow God lands on them with his club/_is in time to the music of drums and pipes,/God in all‐out, two‐fisted battle,/_fighting against them.

18251.text: /Topheth’s fierce fires are well prepared,/_ready for the Assyrian king./The Topheth furnace is deep and wide,/_well stoked with hot‐burning wood./God’s breath, like a river of burning pitch,/_starts the fire.

18252.text: §¶Doom to those who go off to Egypt/_thinking that horses can help them,/Impressed by military mathematics,/_awed by sheer numbers of chariots and riders—/And to The Holy of Israel, not even a glance,/_not so much as a prayer to God.

18253.text: /Still, he must be reckoned with,/_a most wise God who knows what he’s doing./He can call down catastrophe./_He’s a God who does what he says./He intervenes in the work of those who do wrong,/_stands up against interfering evildoers.

18254.text: /Egyptians are mortal, not God,/_and their horses are flesh, not Spirit./When God gives the signal, helpers and helped alike/_will fall in a heap and share the same dirt grave.

18255.text: ¶This is what God told me: ¶▼“Like a lion, king of the beasts,/_that gnaws and chews and worries its prey,/Not fazed in the least by a bunch of shepherds/_who arrive to chase it off,/So God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies comes down/_to fight on Mount Zion, to make war from its heights.

18256.text: /And like a huge eagle hovering in the sky,/_God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies protects Jerusalem./I’ll protect and rescue it./_Yes, I’ll hover and deliver.”

18257.text: ¶Repent, return, dear Israel, to the One you so cruelly abandoned.

18258.text: On the day you return, you’ll throw away—every last one of you—the no‐gods your sinful hands made from metal and wood.

18259.text: ¶“Assyrians will fall dead,/_killed by a sword‐thrust but not by a soldier,/_laid low by a sword not swung by a mortal./Assyrians will run from that sword, run for their lives,/_and their prize young men made slaves.

18260.text: /Terrorized, that rock‐solid people will fall to pieces,/_their leaders scatter hysterically.”/God’s Decree on Assyria./_His fire blazes in Zion,/_his furnace burns hot in Jerusalem.

18261.text: §¶But look! A king will rule in the right way,/_and his leaders will carry out justice.

18262.text: /Each one will stand as a shelter from high winds,/_provide safe cover in stormy weather./Each will be cool running water in parched land,/_a huge granite outcrop giving shade in the desert.

18263.text: /Anyone who looks will see,/_anyone who listens will hear.

18264.text: /The impulsive will make sound decisions,/_the tongue‐tied will speak with eloquence.

18265.text: /No more will fools become celebrities,/_nor crooks be rewarded with fame.

18266.text: /For fools are fools and that’s that,/_thinking up new ways to do mischief./They leave a wake of wrecked lives/_and lies about God,/Turning their backs on the homeless hungry,/_ignoring those dying of thirst in the streets.

18267.text: /And the crooks? Underhanded sneaks they are,/_inventive in sin and scandal,/Exploiting the poor with scams and lies,/_unmoved by the victimized poor.

18268.text: /But those who are noble make noble plans,/_and stand for what is noble.

18269.text: ¶Take your stand, indolent women!/_Listen to me!/Indulgent, indolent women,/_listen closely to what I have to say.

18270.text: /In just a little over a year from now,/_you’ll be shaken out of your lazy lives./The grape harvest will fail,/_and there’ll be no fruit on the trees.

18271.text: /Oh tremble, you indolent women./_Get serious, you pampered dolls!/Strip down and discard your silk fineries./_Put on funeral clothes.

18272.text: /Shed honest tears for the lost harvest,/_the failed vintage./Weep for my people’s gardens and farms

18273.text: /_that grow nothing but thistles and thornbushes./Cry tears, real tears, for the happy homes no longer happy,/_the merry city no longer merry.

18274.text: /The royal palace is deserted,/_the bustling city quiet as a morgue,/The emptied parks and playgrounds/_taken over by wild animals,/_delighted with their new home.

18275.text: ¶Yes, weep and grieve until the Spirit is poured/_down on us from above/And the badlands desert grows crops/_and the fertile fields become forests.

18276.text: /Justice will move into the badlands desert./_Right will build a home in the fertile field.

18277.text: /And where there’s Right, there’ll be Peace/_and the progeny of Right: quiet lives and endless trust.

18278.text: /My people will live in a peaceful neighborhood—/_in safe houses, in quiet gardens.

18279.text: /The forest of your pride will be clear‐cut,/_the city showing off your power leveled.

18280.text: /But you will enjoy a blessed life,/_planting well‐watered fields and gardens,/_with your farm animals grazing freely.

18281.text: §¶Doom to you, Destroyer,/_not yet destroyed;/And doom to you, Betrayer,/_not yet betrayed./When you finish destroying,/_your turn will come—destroyed!/When you quit betraying,/_your turn will come—betrayed!

18282.text: ¶God, treat us kindly. You’re our only hope./_First thing in the morning, be there for us!/_When things go bad, help us out!

18283.text: /You spoke in thunder and everyone ran./_You showed up and nations scattered.

18284.text: /Your people, for a change, got in on the loot,/_picking the field clean of the enemy spoils.

18285.text: ¶God is supremely esteemed. His center holds./_Zion brims over with all that is just and right.

18286.text: /God keeps your days stable and secure—/_salvation, wisdom, and knowledge in surplus,/_and best of all, Zion’s treasure, Fear‐of‐God.

18287.text: ¶But look! Listen!/_Tough men weep openly./_Peacemaking diplomats are in bitter tears.

18288.text: /The roads are empty—/_not a soul out on the streets./The peace treaty is broken,/_its conditions violated,/_its signers reviled.

18289.text: /The very ground under our feet mourns,/_the Lebanon mountains hang their heads,/Flowering Sharon is a weed‐choked gully,/_and the forests of Bashan and Carmel? Bare branches.

18290.text: ¶“Now I’m stepping in,” God says./_“From now on, I’m taking over./_The gloves come off. Now see how mighty I am./There’s nothing to you.

18291.text: /_Pregnant with chaff, you produce straw babies;/_full of hot air, you self‐destruct.

18292.text: /You’re good for nothing but fertilizer and fuel./_Earth to earth—and the sooner the better.

18293.text: ¶“If you’re far away,/_get the reports on what I’ve done,/And if you’re in the neighborhood,/_pay attention to my record.

18294.text: /The sinners in Zion are rightly terrified;/_the godless are at their wit’s end:/‘Who among us can survive this firestorm?/_Who of us can get out of this purge with our lives?’”

18295.text: ¶The answer’s simple:/_Live right,/_speak the truth,/_despise exploitation,/_refuse bribes,/_reject violence,/_avoid evil amusements.

18296.text: /This is how you raise your standard of living!/_A safe and stable way to live./_A nourishing, satisfying way to live.

18297.text: §¶Oh, you’ll see the king—a beautiful sight!/_And you’ll take in the wide vistas of land.

18298.text: /In your mind you’ll go over the old terrors:/_“What happened to that Assyrian inspector who condemned and confiscated?/And the one who gouged us of taxes?/_And that cheating moneychanger?”

18299.text: /Gone! Out of sight forever! Their insolence/_nothing now but a fading stain on the carpet!/No more putting up with a language you can’t understand,/_no more sounds of gibberish in your ears.

18300.text: ¶Just take a look at Zion, will you?/_Centering our worship in festival feasts!/Feast your eyes on Jerusalem,/_a quiet and permanent place to live./No more pulling up stakes and moving on,/_no more patched‐together lean‐tos.

18301.text: /Instead, God! God majestic, God himself the place/_in a country of broad rivers and streams,/But rivers blocked to invading ships,/_off‐limits to predatory pirates.

18302.text: /For God makes all the decisions here. God is our king./_God runs this place and he’ll keep us safe.

18303.text: ¶Ha! Your sails are in shreds,/_your mast wobbling,/_your hold leaking./The plunder is free for the taking, free for all—/_for weak and strong, insiders and outsiders.

18304.text: ¶No one in Zion will say, “I’m sick.”/_Best of all, they’ll all live guilt‐free.

18305.text: §¶Draw in close now, nations. Listen carefully,/_you people. Pay attention!/Earth, you, too, and everything in you./_World, and all that comes from you.

18306.text: ¶And here’s why: God is angry,/_good and angry with all the nations,/So blazingly angry at their arms and armies/_that he’s going to rid earth of them, wipe them out.

18307.text: /The corpses, thrown in a heap,/_will stink like the town dump in midsummer,/Their blood flowing off the mountains/_like creeks in spring runoff.

18308.text: /Stars will fall out of the sky/_like overripe, rotting fruit in the orchard,/And the sky itself will be folded up like a blanket/_and put away in a closet./All that army of stars, shriveled to nothing,/_like leaves and fruit in autumn, dropping and rotting!

18309.text: ¶“Once I’ve finished with earth and sky,/_I’ll start in on Edom./I’ll come down hard on Edom,/_a people I’ve slated for total termination.”

18310.text: /God has a sword, thirsty for blood and more blood,/_a sword hungry for well‐fed flesh,/Lamb and goat blood,/_the suet‐rich kidneys of rams./Yes, God has scheduled a sacrifice in Bozrah, the capital,/_the whole country of Edom a slaughterhouse.

18311.text: /A wholesale slaughter, wild animals/_and farm animals alike slaughtered./The whole country soaked with blood,/_all the ground greasy with fat.

18312.text: ¶It’s God’s scheduled time for vengeance,/_the year all Zion’s accounts are settled.

18313.text: /Edom’s streams will flow sluggish, thick with pollution,/_the soil sterile, poisoned with waste,/The whole country/_a smoking, stinking garbage dump—

18314.text: /The fires burning day and night,/_the skies black with endless smoke./Generation after generation of wasteland—/_no more travelers through this country!

18315.text: /Vultures and skunks will police the streets;/_owls and crows will feel at home there./God will reverse creation. Chaos!/_He will cancel fertility. Emptiness!

18316.text: /Leaders will have no one to lead./_They’ll name it No Kingdom There,/A country where all kings/_and princes are unemployed.

18317.text: /Thistles will take over, covering the castles,/_fortresses conquered by weeds and thornbushes./Wild dogs will prowl the ruins,/_ostriches have the run of the place.

18318.text: /Wildcats and hyenas will hunt together,/_demons and devils dance through the night./The night‐demon Lilith, evil and rapacious,/_will establish permanent quarters.

18319.text: /Scavenging carrion birds will breed and brood,/_infestations of ominous evil.

18320.text: ¶Get and read God’s book:/_None of this is going away,/_this breeding, brooding evil./God has personally commanded it all./_His Spirit set it in motion.

18321.text: /God has assigned them their place,/_decreed their fate in detail./This is permanent—/_generation after generation, the same old thing.

18322.text: §¶Wilderness and desert will sing joyously,/_the badlands will celebrate and flower—

18323.text: /Like the crocus in spring, bursting into blossom,/_a symphony of song and color./Mountain glories of Lebanon—a gift./_Awesome Carmel, stunning Sharon—gifts./God’s resplendent glory, fully on display./_God awesome, God majestic.

18324.text: ¶Energize the limp hands,/_strengthen the rubbery knees.

18325.text: /Tell fearful souls,/_“Courage! Take heart!/God is here, right here,/_on his way to put things right/And redress all wrongs./_He’s on his way! He’ll save you!”

18326.text: ¶Blind eyes will be opened,/_deaf ears unstopped,

18327.text: /Lame men and women will leap like deer,/_the voiceless break into song./Springs of water will burst out in the wilderness,/_streams flow in the desert.

18328.text: /Hot sands will become a cool oasis,/_thirsty ground a splashing fountain./Even lowly jackals will have water to drink,/_and barren grasslands flourish richly.

18329.text: ¶There will be a highway/_called the Holy Road./No one rude or rebellious/_is permitted on this road./It’s for God’s people exclusively—/_impossible to get lost on this road./_Not even fools can get lost on it.

18330.text: /No lions on this road,/_no dangerous wild animals—/Nothing and no one dangerous or threatening./_Only the redeemed will walk on it.

18331.text: /The people God has ransomed/_will come back on this road./They’ll sing as they make their way home to Zion,/_unfading halos of joy encircling their heads,/Welcomed home with gifts of joy and gladness/_as all sorrows and sighs scurry into the night.

18332.text: §¶In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, Sennacherib king of Assyria made war on all the fortress cities of Judah and took them.

18333.text: Then the king of Assyria sent his general, the “Rabshekah,” accompanied by a huge army, from Lachish to Jerusalem to King Hezekiah. The general stopped at the aqueduct where it empties into the upper pool on the road to the public laundry.

18334.text: Three men went out to meet him: Eliakim son of Hilkiah, in charge of the palace; Shebna the secretary; and Joah son of Asaph, the official historian.

18335.text: ¶The Rabshekah said to them, “Tell Hezekiah that the Great King, the king of Assyria, says this: ‘What kind of backing do you think you have against me?

18336.text: You’re bluffing and I’m calling your bluff. Your words are no match for my weapons. What kind of backup do you have now that you’ve rebelled against me?

18337.text: Egypt? Don’t make me laugh. Egypt is a rubber crutch. Lean on Egypt and you’ll end up flat on your face. That’s all Pharaoh king of Egypt is to anyone who leans on him.

18338.text: And if you try to tell me, “We’re leaning on our God,” isn’t it a bit late? Hasn’t Hezekiah just gotten rid of all the places of worship, telling you, “You’ve got to worship at this altar”?

18339.text: ¶“‘Be reasonable. Face the facts: My master the king of Assyria will give you two thousand horses if you can put riders on them.

18340.text: You can’t do it, can you? So how do you think, depending on flimsy Egypt’s chariots and riders, you can stand up against even the lowest‐ranking captain in my master’s army?

18341.text: ¶“‘And besides, do you think I came all this way to destroy this land without first getting God’s blessing? It was your God who told me, Make war on this land. Destroy it.’”

18342.text: ¶Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah answered the Rabshekah, “Please talk to us in Aramaic. We understand Aramaic. Don’t talk to us in Hebrew within earshot of all the people gathered around.”

18343.text: ¶But the Rabshekah replied, “Do you think my master has sent me to give this message to your master and you but not also to the people clustered here? It’s their fate that’s at stake. They’re the ones who are going to end up eating their own excrement and drinking their own urine.”

18344.text: ¶Then the Rabshekah stood up and called out loudly in Hebrew, the common language, “Listen to the message of the great king, the king of Assyria!

18345.text: Don’t listen to Hezekiah’s lies. He can’t save you.

18346.text: And don’t pay any attention to Hezekiah’s pious sermons telling you to lean on God, telling you ‘God will save us, depend on it. God won’t let this city fall to the king of Assyria.’

18347.text: ¶“Don’t listen to Hezekiah. Listen to the king of Assyria’s offer: ‘Make peace with me. Come and join me. Everyone will end up with a good life, with plenty of land and water,

18349.text: I’ll turn you loose in wide open spaces, with more than enough fertile and productive land for everyone.’ Don’t let Hezekiah mislead you with his lies, ‘God will save us.’ Has that ever happened? Has any god in history ever gotten the best of the king of Assyria?

18350.text: Look around you. Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? The gods of Sepharvaim? Did the gods do anything for Samaria?

18351.text: Name one god that has ever saved its countries from me. So what makes you think that God could save Jerusalem from me?’”

18352.text: ¶The three men were silent. They said nothing, for the king had already commanded, “Don’t answer him.”

18353.text: ¶Then Eliakim son of Hilkiah, the palace administrator, Shebna the secretary, and Joah son of Asaph, the court historian, tearing their clothes in defeat and despair, went back and reported what the Rabshekah had said to Hezekiah.

18354.text: §¶When King Hezekiah heard the report, he also tore his clothes and dressed in rough, penitential burlap gunnysacks, and went into the sanctuary of God.

18355.text: He sent Eliakim the palace administrator, Shebna the secretary, and the senior priests, all of them also dressed in penitential burlap, to the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz.

18356.text: ¶They said to him, “Hezekiah says, ‘This is a black day. We’re in crisis. We’re like pregnant women without even the strength to have a baby!

18357.text: Do you think your God heard what the Rabshekah said, sent by his master the king of Assyria to mock the living God? And do you think your God will do anything about it? Pray for us, Isaiah. Pray for those of us left here holding the fort!’”

18358.text: ¶Then King Hezekiah’s servants came to Isaiah.

18359.text: Isaiah said, “Tell your master this, ‘God’s Message: Don’t be upset by what you’ve heard, all those words the servants of the Assyrian king have used to mock me.

18360.text: I personally will take care of him. I’ll arrange it so that he’ll get a rumor of bad news back home and rush home to take care of it. And he’ll die there. Killed—a violent death.’”

18361.text: ¶The Rabshekah left and found the king of Assyria fighting against Libnah. (He had gotten word that the king had left Lachish.)

18362.text: ¶Just then the Assyrian king received an intelligence report on King Tirhakah of Ethiopia: “He is on his way to make war on you.”¶On hearing that, he sent messengers to Hezekiah with instructions to deliver this message:

18363.text: “Don’t let your God, on whom you so naively lean, deceive you, promising that Jerusalem won’t fall to the king of Assyria. Use your head!

18364.text: Look around at what the kings of Assyria have done all over the world—one country after another devastated! And do you think you’re going to get off?

18365.text: Have any of the gods of any of these countries ever stepped in and saved them, even one of these nations my predecessors destroyed—Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the people of Eden who lived in Telassar?

18366.text: Look around. Do you see anything left of the king of Hamath, the king of Arpad, the king of the city of Sepharvaim, the king of Hena, the king of Ivvah?”

18367.text: ¶Hezekiah took the letter from the hands of the messengers and read it. Then he went into the sanctuary of God and spread the letter out before God.

18369.text: “God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies, enthroned over the cherubim‐angels, you are God, the only God there is, God of all kingdoms on earth. You made heaven and earth.

18370.text: Listen, O God, and hear. Look, O God, and see. Mark all these words of Sennacherib that he sent to mock the living God.

18371.text: It’s quite true, O God, that the kings of Assyria have devastated all the nations and their lands.

18372.text: They’ve thrown their gods into the trash and burned them—no great achievement since they were no‐gods anyway, gods made in workshops, carved from wood and chiseled from rock.

18373.text: An end to the no‐gods! But now step in, O God, our God. Save us from him. Let all the kingdoms of earth know that you and you alone are God.”

18374.text: ¶Then Isaiah son of Amoz sent this word to Hezekiah: “God’s Message, the God of Israel:

18375.text: Because you brought King Sennacherib of Assyria to me in prayer, here is my answer, God’s answer: ¶▼“‘She has no use for you, Sennacherib, nothing but contempt,/_this virgin daughter Zion./She spits at you and turns on her heel,

18376.text: /_this daughter Jerusalem.¶“‘Who do you think you’ve been mocking and reviling/_all these years?/Who do you think you’ve been jeering/_and treating with such utter contempt/All these years?/_The Holy of Israel!

18377.text: /You’ve used your servants to mock the Master./_You’ve bragged, “With my fleet of chariots/I’ve gone to the highest mountain ranges,/_penetrated the far reaches of Lebanon,/Chopped down its giant cedars,/_its finest cypresses./I conquered its highest peak,/_explored its deepest forest.

18378.text: /I dug wells/_and drank my fill./I emptied the famous rivers of Egypt/_with one kick of my foot.

18379.text: ¶“‘Haven’t you gotten the news/_that I’ve been behind this all along?/This is a longstanding plan of mine/_and I’m just now making it happen,/using you to devastate strong cities,/_turning them into piles of rubble

18380.text: /and leaving their citizens helpless,/_bewildered, and confused,/drooping like unwatered plants,/_stunted like withered seedlings.

18381.text: ¶“‘I know all about your pretentious poses,/_your officious comings and goings,/_and, yes, the tantrums you throw against me.

18382.text: /Because of all your wild raging against me,/_your unbridled arrogance that I keep hearing of,/I’ll put my hook in your nose/_and my bit in your mouth./I’ll show you who’s boss. I’ll turn you around/_and take you back to where you came from.

18383.text: ¶“‘And this, Hezekiah, will be your confirming sign: This year’s crops will be slim pickings, and next year it won’t be much better. But in three years, farming will be back to normal, with regular sowing and reaping, planting and harvesting.

18384.text: What’s left of the people of Judah will put down roots and make a new start.

18385.text: The people left in Jerusalem will get moving again. Mount Zion survivors will take hold again. The zeal of God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies will do all this.’

18386.text: ¶“Finally, this is God’s verdict on the king of Assyria: ¶▼“‘Don’t worry, he won’t enter this city,/_won’t let loose a single arrow,/Won’t brandish so much as one shield,/_let alone build a siege ramp against it.

18387.text: /He’ll go back the same way he came./_He won’t set a foot in this city./_God’s Decree.

18388.text: /I’ve got my hand on this city/_to save it,/Save it for my very own sake,/_but also for the sake of my David dynasty.’”

18389.text: ¶Then the Angel of God arrived and struck the Assyrian camp—185,000 Assyrians died. By the time the sun came up, they were all dead—an army of corpses!

18390.text: Sennacherib, king of Assyria, got out of there fast, back home to Nineveh.

18391.text: As he was worshiping in the sanctuary of his god Nisroch, he was murdered by his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer. They escaped to the land of Ararat. His son Esar‐haddon became the next king.

18392.text: §¶At that time, Hezekiah got sick. He was about to die. The prophet Isaiah son of Amoz visited him and said, “God says, ‘Prepare your affairs and your family. This is it: You’re going to die. You’re not going to get well.’”

18393.text: ¶Hezekiah turned away from Isaiah and, facing the wall, prayed to God:

18394.text: “God, please, I beg you: Remember how I’ve lived my life. I’ve lived faithfully in your presence, lived out of a heart that was totally yours. You’ve seen how I’ve lived, the good that I have done.” And Hezekiah wept as he prayed—painful tears.

18395.text: ¶Then God told Isaiah, “Go and speak with Hezekiah.

18396.text: Give him this Message from me, God, the God of your ancestor David: ‘I’ve heard your prayer. I have seen your tears. Here’s what I’ll do: I’ll add fifteen years to your life.

18397.text: And I’ll save both you and this city from the king of Assyria. I have my hand on this city.

18398.text: ¶“‘And this is your confirming sign, confirming that I, God, will do exactly what I have promised.

18399.text: Watch for this: As the sun goes down and the shadow lengthens on the sundial of Ahaz, I’m going to reverse the shadow ten notches on the dial.’” And that’s what happened: The declining sun’s shadow reversed ten notches on the dial.

18400.text: ¶This is what Hezekiah king of Judah wrote after he’d been sick and then recovered from his sickness:

18401.text: ¶In the very prime of life/_I have to leave./Whatever time I have left/_is spent in death’s waiting room.

18402.text: /No more glimpses of God/_in the land of the living,/No more meetings with my neighbors,/_no more rubbing shoulders with friends.

18403.text: /This body I inhabit is taken down/_and packed away like a camper’s tent./Like a weaver, I’ve rolled up the carpet of my life/_as God cuts me free of the loom/And at day’s end sweeps up the scraps and pieces.

18404.text: /_I cry for help until morning./Like a lion, God pummels and pounds me,/_relentlessly finishing me off.

18405.text: /I squawk like a doomed hen,/_moan like a dove./My eyes ache from looking up for help:/_“Master, I’m in trouble! Get me out of this!”

18406.text: /But what’s the use? God himself gave me the word./_He’s done it to me./I can’t sleep—/_I’m that upset, that troubled.

18407.text: ¶O Master, these are the conditions in which people live,/_and yes, in these very conditions my spirit is still alive—/_fully recovered with a fresh infusion of life!

18408.text: /It seems it was good for me/_to go through all those troubles./Throughout them all you held tight to my lifeline./_You never let me tumble over the edge into nothing./But my sins you let go of,/_threw them over your shoulder—good riddance!

18409.text: /The dead don’t thank you,/_and choirs don’t sing praises from the morgue./Those buried six feet under/_don’t witness to your faithful ways.

18410.text: /It’s the living—live men, live women—who thank you,/_just as I’m doing right now./Parents give their children/_full reports on your faithful ways.

18411.text: ¶God saves and will save me./_As fiddles and mandolins strike up the tunes,/We’ll sing, oh we’ll sing, sing,/_for the rest of our lives in the Sanctuary of God.

18412.text: ¶Isaiah had said, “Prepare a poultice of figs and put it on the boil so he may recover.”

18413.text: ¶Hezekiah had said, “What is my cue that it’s all right to enter again the Sanctuary of God?”

18414.text: §¶Sometime later, King Merodach‐baladan son of Baladan of Babylon sent messengers with greetings and a gift to Hezekiah. He had heard that Hezekiah had been sick and was now well.

18415.text: ¶Hezekiah received the messengers warmly. He took them on a tour of his royal precincts, proudly showing them all his treasures: silver, gold, spices, expensive oils, all his weapons—everything out on display. There was nothing in his house or kingdom that Hezekiah didn’t show them.

18416.text: ¶Later the prophet Isaiah showed up. He asked Hezekiah, “What were these men up to? What did they say? And where did they come from?”¶Hezekiah said, “They came from a long way off, from Babylon.”

18417.text: ¶“And what did they see in your palace?”¶“Everything,” said Hezekiah. “I showed them the works, opened all the doors and impressed them with it all.”

18418.text: ¶Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, “Now listen to this Message from God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies:

18419.text: I have to warn you, the time is coming when everything in this palace, along with everything your ancestors accumulated before you, will be hauled off to Babylon. God says that there will be nothing left. Nothing.

18420.text: And not only your things but your sons. Some of your sons will be taken into exile, ending up as eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon.”

18421.text: ¶Hezekiah replied to Isaiah, “Good. If God says so, it’s good.” Within himself he was thinking, “But surely nothing bad will happen in my lifetime. I’ll enjoy peace and stability as long as I live.”

18422.text: Messages of Comfort§¶“Comfort, oh comfort my people,”/_says your God.

18423.text: /“Speak softly and tenderly to Jerusalem,/_but also make it very clear/That she has served her sentence,/_that her sin is taken care of—forgiven!/She’s been punished enough and more than enough,/_and now it’s over and done with.”

18424.text: ¶Thunder in the desert!/_“Prepare for God’s arrival!/Make the road straight and smooth,/_a highway fit for our God.

18425.text: /Fill in the valleys,/_level off the hills,/Smooth out the ruts,/_clear out the rocks.

18426.text: /Then God’s bright glory will shine/_and everyone will see it./_Yes. Just as God has said.”

18427.text: ¶A voice says, “Shout!”/_I said, “What shall I shout?”¶“These people are nothing but grass,/_their love fragile as wildflowers.

18428.text: /The grass withers, the wildflowers fade,/_if God so much as puffs on them./_Aren’t these people just so much grass?

18429.text: /True, the grass withers and the wildflowers fade,/_but our God’s Word stands firm and forever.”

18430.text: ¶Climb a high mountain, Zion./_You’re the preacher of good news./Raise your voice. Make it good and loud, Jerusalem./_You’re the preacher of good news./_Speak loud and clear. Don’t be timid!/Tell the cities of Judah,/_“Look! Your God!”

18431.text: /Look at him! God, the Master, comes in power,/_ready to go into action./He is going to pay back his enemies/_and reward those who have loved him.

18432.text: /Like a shepherd, he will care for his flock,/_gathering the lambs in his arms,/Hugging them as he carries them,/_leading the nursing ewes to good pasture.

18433.text: §¶Who has scooped up the ocean/_in his two hands,/_or measured the sky between his thumb and little finger,/Who has put all the earth’s dirt in one of his baskets,/_weighed each mountain and hill?

18434.text: /Who could ever have told God what to do/_or taught him his business?/What expert would he have gone to for advice,

18435.text: /_what school would he attend to learn justice?/What god do you suppose might have taught him what he knows,/_showed him how things work?

18436.text: /Why, the nations are but a drop in a bucket,/_a mere smudge on a window./Watch him sweep up the islands/_like so much dust off the floor!

18437.text: /There aren’t enough trees in Lebanon/_nor enough animals in those vast forests/_to furnish adequate fuel and offerings for his worship.

18438.text: /All the nations add up to simply nothing before him—/_less than nothing is more like it. A minus.

18439.text: ¶So who even comes close to being like God?/_To whom or what can you compare him?/Some no‐god idol? Ridiculous!

18440.text: /_It’s made in a workshop, cast in bronze,/Given a thin veneer of gold,/_and draped with silver filigree.

18441.text: /Or, perhaps someone will select a fine wood—/_olive wood, say—that won’t rot,/Then hire a woodcarver to make a no‐god,/_giving special care to its base so it won’t tip over!

18442.text: ¶Have you not been paying attention?/_Have you not been listening?/Haven’t you heard these stories all your life?/_Don’t you understand the foundation of all things?

18443.text: /God sits high above the round ball of earth./_The people look like mere ants./He stretches out the skies like a canvas—/_yes, like a tent canvas to live under.

18444.text: /He ignores what all the princes say and do./_The rulers of the earth count for nothing.

18445.text: /Princes and rulers don’t amount to much./_Like seeds barely rooted, just sprouted,/They shrivel when God blows on them./_Like flecks of chaff, they’re gone with the wind.

18446.text: ¶“So—who is like me?/_Who holds a candle to me?” says The Holy.

18447.text: /Look at the night skies:/_Who do you think made all this?/Who marches this army of stars out each night,/_counts them off, calls each by name/—so magnificent! so powerful!—/_and never overlooks a single one?

18448.text: ¶Why would you ever complain, O Jacob,/_or, whine, Israel, saying,/“God has lost track of me./_He doesn’t care what happens to me”?

18449.text: /Don’t you know anything? Haven’t you been listening?/God doesn’t come and go. God lasts./_He’s Creator of all you can see or imagine./He doesn’t get tired out, doesn’t pause to catch his breath./_And he knows everything, inside and out.

18450.text: /He energizes those who get tired,/_gives fresh strength to dropouts.

18451.text: /For even young people tire and drop out,/_young folk in their prime stumble and fall.

18452.text: /But those who wait upon God get fresh strength./_They spread their wings and soar like eagles,/They run and don’t get tired,/_they walk and don’t lag behind.

18453.text: §¶“Quiet down, far‐flung ocean islands. Listen!/_Sit down and rest, everyone. Recover your strength./Gather around me. Say what’s on your heart./_Together let’s decide what’s right.

18454.text: ¶“Who got things rolling here,/_got this champion from the east on the move?/Who recruited him for this job,/_then rounded up and corralled the nations/_so he could run roughshod over kings?/He’s off and running,/_pulverizing nations into dust,/_leaving only stubble and chaff in his wake.

18455.text: /He chases them and comes through unscathed,/_his feet scarcely touching the path.

18456.text: ¶“Who did this? Who made it happen?/_Who always gets things started?/I did. God. I’m first on the scene./_I’m also the last to leave.

18457.text: ¶“Far‐flung ocean islands see it and panic./_The ends of the earth are shaken./_Fearfully they huddle together.

18458.text: /They try to help each other out,/_making up stories in the dark.

18459.text: /The godmakers in the workshops/_go into overtime production, crafting new models of no‐gods,/Urging one another on—‘Good job!’ ‘Great design!’—/_pounding in nails at the base/_so that the things won’t tip over.

18460.text: ¶“But you, Israel, are my servant./_You’re Jacob, my first choice,/_descendants of my good friend Abraham.

18461.text: /I pulled you in from all over the world,/_called you in from every dark corner of the earth,/Telling you, ‘You’re my servant, serving on my side./_I’ve picked you. I haven’t dropped you.’

18462.text: /Don’t panic. I’m with you./_There’s no need to fear for I’m your God./I’ll give you strength. I’ll help you./_I’ll hold you steady, keep a firm grip on you.

18463.text: ¶“Count on it: Everyone who had it in for you/_will end up out in the cold—/_real losers./Those who worked against you/_will end up empty‐handed—/_nothing to show for their lives.

18464.text: /When you go out looking for your old adversaries/_you won’t find them—/Not a trace of your old enemies,/_not even a memory./That’s right.

18465.text: Because I, your God,/_have a firm grip on you and I’m not letting go./I’m telling you, ‘Don’t panic./_I’m right here to help you.’

18466.text: ¶“Do you feel like a lowly worm, Jacob?/_Don’t be afraid./Feel like a fragile insect, Israel?/_I’ll help you./I, God, want to reassure you./_The God who buys you back, The Holy of Israel.

18467.text: /I’m transforming you from worm to harrow,/_from insect to iron./As a sharp‐toothed harrow you’ll smooth out the mountains,/_turn those tough old hills into loamy soil.

18468.text: /You’ll open the rough ground to the weather,/_to the blasts of sun and wind and rain./But you’ll be confident and exuberant,/_expansive in The Holy of Israel!

18469.text: ¶“The poor and homeless are desperate for water,/_their tongues parched and no water to be found./But I’m there to be found, I’m there for them,/_and I, God of Israel, will not leave them thirsty.

18470.text: /I’ll open up rivers for them on the barren hills,/_spout fountains in the valleys./I’ll turn the baked‐clay badlands into a cool pond,/_the waterless waste into splashing creeks.

18471.text: /I’ll plant the red cedar in that treeless wasteland,/_also acacia, myrtle, and olive./I’ll place the cypress in the desert,/_with plenty of oaks and pines.

18472.text: /Everyone will see this. No one can miss it—/_unavoidable, indisputable evidence/That I, God, personally did this./_It’s created and signed by The Holy of Israel.

18473.text: ¶“Set out your case for your gods,” says God./_“Bring your evidence,” says the King of Jacob.

18474.text: /“Take the stand on behalf of your idols, offer arguments,/_assemble reasons./Spread out the facts before us/_so that we can assess them ourselves.

18475.text: /Ask them, ‘If you are gods, explain what the past means—/_or, failing that, tell us what will happen in the future./Can’t do that?/_How about doing something—anything!/Good or bad—whatever./_Can you hurt us or help us? Do we need to be afraid?’

18476.text: /They say nothing, because they are nothing—/_sham gods, no‐gods, fool‐making gods.

18477.text: ¶“I, God, started someone out from the north and he’s come./_He was called out of the east by name./He’ll stomp the rulers into the mud/_the way a potter works the clay.

18478.text: /Let me ask you, Did anyone guess that this might happen?/_Did anyone tell us earlier so we might confirm it/_with ‘Yes, he’s right!’?/No one mentioned it, no one announced it,/_no one heard a peep out of you.

18479.text: /But I told Zion all about this beforehand./_I gave Jerusalem a preacher of good news.

18480.text: /But around here there’s no one—/_no one who knows what’s going on./_I ask, but no one can tell me the score.

18481.text: /Nothing here. It’s all smoke and hot air—/_sham gods, hollow gods, no‐gods.”

18482.text: §¶“Take a good look at my servant./_I’m backing him to the hilt./He’s the one I chose,/_and I couldn’t be more pleased with him./I’ve bathed him with my Spirit, my life./_He’ll set everything right among the nations.

18483.text: /He won’t call attention to what he does/_with loud speeches or gaudy parades.

18484.text: /He won’t brush aside the bruised and the hurt/_and he won’t disregard the small and insignificant,/_but he’ll steadily and firmly set things right.

18485.text: /He won’t tire out and quit. He won’t be stopped/_until he’s finished his work—to set things right on earth./Far‐flung ocean islands/_wait expectantly for his teaching.”

18486.text: §¶God’s Message,/_the God who created the cosmos, stretched out the skies,/_laid out the earth and all that grows from it,/Who breathes life into earth’s people,/_makes them alive with his own life:

18487.text: /“I am God. I have called you to live right and well./_I have taken responsibility for you, kept you safe./I have set you among my people to bind them to me,/_and provided you as a lighthouse to the nations,

18488.text: /To make a start at bringing people into the open, into light:/_opening blind eyes,/_releasing prisoners from dungeons,/_emptying the dark prisons.

18489.text: /I am God. That’s my name./_I don’t franchise my glory,/_don’t endorse the no‐god idols.

18490.text: /Take note: The earlier predictions of judgment have been fulfilled./_I’m announcing the new salvation work./Before it bursts on the scene,/_I’m telling you all about it.”

18491.text: ¶Sing to God a brand‐new song,/_sing his praises all over the world!/Let the sea and its fish give a round of applause,/_with all the far‐flung islands joining in.

18492.text: /Let the desert and its camps raise a tune,/_calling the Kedar nomads to join in./Let the villagers in Sela round up a choir/_and perform from the tops of the mountains.

18493.text: /Make God’s glory resound;/_echo his praises from coast to coast.

18494.text: /God steps out like he means business./_You can see he’s primed for action./He shouts, announcing his arrival;/_he takes charge and his enemies fall into line:¶“I’ve been quiet long enough.

18495.text: /_I’ve held back, biting my tongue./But now I’m letting loose, letting go,/_like a woman who’s having a baby—

18496.text: /Stripping the hills bare,/_withering the wildflowers,/Drying up the rivers,/_turning lakes into mudflats.

18497.text: /But I’ll take the hand of those who don’t know the way,/_who can’t see where they’re going./I’ll be a personal guide to them,/_directing them through unknown country./I’ll be right there to show them what roads to take,/_make sure they don’t fall into the ditch./These are the things I’ll be doing for them—/_sticking with them, not leaving them for a minute.”

18498.text: ¶But those who invested in the no‐gods/_are bankrupt—dead broke.

18499.text: §¶Pay attention! Are you deaf?/_Open your eyes! Are you blind?

18500.text: /You’re my servant, and you’re not looking!/_You’re my messenger, and you’re not listening!/The very people I depended upon, servants of God,/_blind as a bat—willfully blind!

18501.text: /You’ve seen a lot, but looked at nothing./_You’ve heard everything, but listened to nothing.

18502.text: /God intended, out of the goodness of his heart,/_to be lavish in his revelation.

18503.text: /But this is a people battered and cowed,/_shut up in attics and closets,/Victims licking their wounds,/_feeling ignored, abandoned.

18504.text: /But is anyone out there listening?/_Is anyone paying attention to what’s coming?

18505.text: /Who do you think turned Jacob over to the thugs,/_let loose the robbers on Israel?/Wasn’t it God himself, this God against whom we’ve sinned—/_not doing what he commanded,/_not listening to what he said?

18506.text: /Isn’t it God’s anger that’s behind all this,/_God’s punishing power?/Their whole world collapsed but they still didn’t get it;/_their life is in ruins but they don’t take it to heart.

18507.text: §¶But now, God’s Message,/_the God who made you in the first place, Jacob,/_the One who got you started, Israel:/“Don’t be afraid, I’ve redeemed you./_I’ve called your name. You’re mine.

18508.text: /When you’re in over your head, I’ll be there with you./_When you’re in rough waters, you will not go down./When you’re between a rock and a hard place,/_it won’t be a dead end—

18509.text: /Because I am God, your personal God,/_The Holy of Israel, your Savior./I paid a huge price for you:/_all of Egypt, with rich Cush and Seba thrown in!

18510.text: /That’s how much you mean to me!/_That’s how much I love you!/I’d sell off the whole world to get you back,/_trade the creation just for you.

18511.text: ¶“So don’t be afraid: I’m with you./_I’ll round up all your scattered children,/_pull them in from east and west.

18512.text: /I’ll send orders north and south:/_‘Send them back./Return my sons from distant lands,/_my daughters from faraway places.

18513.text: /I want them back, every last one who bears my name,/_every man, woman, and child/Whom I created for my glory,/_yes, personally formed and made each one.’”

18514.text: ¶Get the blind and deaf out here and ready—/_the blind (though there’s nothing wrong with their eyes)/_and the deaf (though there’s nothing wrong with their ears).

18515.text: /Then get the other nations out here and ready./_Let’s see what they have to say about this,/_how they account for what’s happened./Let them present their expert witnesses/_and make their case;/_let them try to convince us what they say is true.

18516.text: /“But you are my witnesses.” God’s Decree./_“You’re my handpicked servant/So that you’ll come to know and trust me,/_understand both that I am and who I am./Previous to me there was no such thing as a god,/_nor will there be after me.

18517.text: /I, yes I, am God./_I’m the only Savior there is.

18518.text: /I spoke, I saved, I told you what existed/_long before these upstart gods appeared on the scene./And you know it, you’re my witnesses,/_you’re the evidence.” God’s Decree./“Yes, I am God.

18519.text: /_I’ve always been God/_and I always will be God./No one can take anything from me./_I make; who can unmake it?”

18520.text: §¶God, your Redeemer,/_The Holy of Israel, says:/“Just for you, I will march on Babylon./_I’ll turn the tables on the Babylonians./Instead of whooping it up,/_they’ll be wailing.

18521.text: /I am God, your Holy One,/_Creator of Israel, your King.”

18522.text: ¶This is what God says,/_the God who builds a road right through the ocean,/_who carves a path through pounding waves,

18523.text: /The God who summons horses and chariots and armies—/_they lie down and then can’t get up;/_they’re snuffed out like so many candles:

18524.text: /“Forget about what’s happened;/_don’t keep going over old history.

18525.text: /Be alert, be present. I’m about to do something brand‐new./_It’s bursting out! Don’t you see it?/There it is! I’m making a road through the desert,/_rivers in the badlands.

18526.text: /Wild animals will say ‘Thank you!’/_—the coyotes and the buzzards—/Because I provided water in the desert,/_rivers through the sun‐baked earth,/Drinking water for the people I chose,

18527.text: /_the people I made especially for myself,/_a people custom‐made to praise me.

18528.text: ¶“But you didn’t pay a bit of attention to me, Jacob./_You so quickly tired of me, Israel.

18529.text: /You wouldn’t even bring sheep for offerings in worship./_You couldn’t be bothered with sacrifices./It wasn’t that I asked that much from you./_I didn’t expect expensive presents.

18530.text: /But you didn’t even do the minimum—/_so stingy with me, so closefisted./Yet you haven’t been stingy with your sins./_You’ve been plenty generous with them—and I’m fed up.

18531.text: ¶“But I, yes I, am the one/_who takes care of your sins—that’s what I do./_I don’t keep a list of your sins.

18532.text: ¶“So, make your case against me. Let’s have this out./_Make your arguments. Prove you’re in the right.

18533.text: /Your original ancestor started the sinning,/_and everyone since has joined in.

18534.text: /That’s why I had to disqualify the Temple leaders,/_repudiate Jacob and discredit Israel.”

18535.text: §¶“But for now, dear servant Jacob, listen—/_yes, you, Israel, my personal choice.

18536.text: /God who made you has something to say to you;/_the God who formed you in the womb wants to help you./Don’t be afraid, dear servant Jacob,/_Jeshurun, the one I chose.

18537.text: /For I will pour water on the thirsty ground/_and send streams coursing through the parched earth./I will pour my Spirit into your descendants

18538.text: /_and my blessing on your children./They shall sprout like grass on the prairie,/_like willows alongside creeks.

18539.text: /This one will say, ‘I am God’s,’/_and another will go by the name Jacob;/That one will write on his hand ‘God’s property’—/_and be proud to be called Israel.”

18540.text: ¶God, King of Israel,/_your Redeemer, God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies, says:/“I’m first, I’m last, and everything in between./_I’m the only God there is.

18541.text: /Who compares with me?/_Speak up. See if you measure up./From the beginning, who else has always announced what’s coming?/_So what is coming next? Anybody want to venture a try?

18542.text: /Don’t be afraid, and don’t worry:/_Haven’t I always kept you informed, told you what was going on?/You’re my eyewitnesses:/_Have you ever come across a God, a real God, other than me?/_There’s no Rock like me that I know of.”

18543.text: §¶All those who make no‐god idols don’t amount to a thing, and what they work so hard at making is nothing. Their little puppet‐gods see nothing and know nothing—they’re total embarrassments!

18544.text: Who would bother making gods that can’t do anything, that can’t “god”?

18545.text: Watch all the no‐god worshipers hide their faces in shame. Watch the no‐god makers slink off humiliated when their idols fail them. Get them out here in the open. Make them face God‐reality.

18546.text: ¶The blacksmith makes his no‐god, works it over in his forge, hammering it on his anvil—such hard work! He works away, fatigued with hunger and thirst.

18547.text: ¶The woodworker draws up plans for his no‐god, traces it on a block of wood. He shapes it with chisels and planes into human shape—a beautiful woman, a handsome man, ready to be placed in a chapel.

18548.text: He first cuts down a cedar, or maybe picks out a pine or oak, and lets it grow strong in the forest, nourished by the rain.

18549.text: Then it can serve a double purpose: Part he uses as firewood for keeping warm and baking bread; from the other part he makes a god that he worships—carves it into a god shape and prays before it.

18550.text: With half he makes a fire to warm himself and barbecue his supper. He eats his fill and sits back satisfied with his stomach full and his feet warmed by the fire: “Ah, this is the life.”

18551.text: And he still has half left for a god, made to his personal design—a handy, convenient no‐god to worship whenever so inclined. Whenever the need strikes him he prays to it, “Save me. You’re my god.”

18552.text: ¶Pretty stupid, wouldn’t you say? Don’t they have eyes in their heads? Are their brains working at all?

18553.text: Doesn’t it occur to them to say, “Half of this tree I used for firewood: I baked bread, roasted meat, and enjoyed a good meal. And now I’ve used the rest to make an abominable no‐god. Here I am praying to a stick of wood!”

18554.text: ¶This lover of emptiness, of nothing, is so out of touch with reality, so far gone, that he can’t even look at what he’s doing, can’t even look at the no‐god stick of wood in his hand and say, “This is crazy.”

18555.text: ¶“Remember these things, O Jacob./_Take it seriously, Israel, that you’re my servant./I made you, shaped you: You’re my servant./_O Israel, I’ll never forget you.

18556.text: /I’ve wiped the slate of all your wrongdoings./_There’s nothing left of your sins./Come back to me, come back./_I’ve redeemed you.”

18557.text: ¶High heavens, sing!/_God has done it./Deep earth, shout!/_And you mountains, sing!/_A forest choir of oaks and pines and cedars!/God has redeemed Jacob./_God’s glory is on display in Israel.

18558.text: ¶God, your Redeemer,/_who shaped your life in your mother’s womb, says:/“I am God. I made all that is./_With no help from you I spread out the skies/_and laid out the earth.”

18559.text: ¶He makes the magicians look ridiculous/_and turns fortunetellers into jokes./He makes the experts look trivial/_and their latest knowledge look silly.

18560.text: /But he backs the word of his servant/_and confirms the counsel of his messengers./He says to Jerusalem, “Be inhabited,”/_and to the cities of Judah, “Be rebuilt,”/_and to the ruins, “I raise you up.”

18561.text: /He says to Ocean, “Dry up./_I’m drying up your rivers.”

18562.text: /He says to Cyrus, “My shepherd—/_everything I want, you’ll do it.”/He says to Jerusalem, “Be built,”/_and to the Temple, “Be established.”

18563.text: §¶God’s Message to his anointed,/_to Cyrus, whom he took by the hand/To give the task of taming the nations,/_of terrifying their kings—/He gave him free rein,/_no restrictions:

18564.text: /“I’ll go ahead of you,/_clearing and paving the road./I’ll break down bronze city gates,/_smash padlocks, kick down barred entrances.

18565.text: /I’ll lead you to buried treasures,/_secret caches of valuables—/Confirmations that it is, in fact, I, God,/_the God of Israel, who calls you by your name.

18566.text: /It’s because of my dear servant Jacob,/_Israel my chosen,/That I’ve singled you out, called you by name,/_and given you this privileged work./_And you don’t even know me!

18567.text: /I am God, the only God there is./_Besides me there are no real gods./I’m the one who armed you for this work,/_though you don’t even know me,

18568.text: /So that everyone, from east to west, will know/_that I have no god‐rivals./_I am God, the only God there is.

18569.text: /I form light and create darkness,/_I make harmonies and create discords./_I, God, do all these things.

18570.text: ¶“Open up, heavens, and rain./_Clouds, pour out buckets of my goodness!/Loosen up, earth, and bloom salvation;/_sprout right living./_I, God, generate all this.

18571.text: /But doom to you who fight your Maker—/_you’re a pot at odds with the potter!/Does clay talk back to the potter:/_‘What are you doing? What clumsy fingers!’

18572.text: /Would a sperm say to a father,/_‘Who gave you permission to use me to make a baby?’/Or a fetus to a mother,/_‘Why have you cooped me up in this belly?’”

18573.text: ¶Thus God, The Holy of Israel, Israel’s Maker, says:/_“Do you question who or what I’m making?/_Are you telling me what I can or cannot do?

18574.text: /I made earth,/_and I created man and woman to live on it./I handcrafted the skies/_and direct all the constellations in their turnings.

18575.text: /And now I’ve got Cyrus on the move./_I’ve rolled out the red carpet before him./He will build my city./_He will bring home my exiles./I didn’t hire him to do this. I told him./_I, God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies.”

18576.text: ¶God says: ¶▼“The workers of Egypt, the merchants of Ethiopia,/_and those statuesque Sabeans/Will all come over to you—all yours./_Docile in chains, they’ll follow you,/Hands folded in reverence, praying before you:/_‘Amazing! God is with you!/_There is no other God—none.’”

18577.text: §¶Clearly, you are a God who works behind the scenes,/_God of Israel, Savior God.

18578.text: /Humiliated, all those others/_will be ashamed to show their faces in public./Out of work and at loose ends, the makers of no‐god idols/_won’t know what to do with themselves.

18579.text: /The people of Israel, though, are saved by you, God,/_saved with an eternal salvation./They won’t be ashamed,/_they won’t be at loose ends, ever.

18580.text: ¶God, Creator of the heavens—/_he is, remember, God./Maker of earth—/_he put it on its foundations, built it from scratch./He didn’t go to all that trouble/_to just leave it empty, nothing in it./_He made it to be lived in./_This God says:¶“I am God,/_the one and only.

18581.text: /I don’t just talk to myself/_or mumble under my breath./I never told Jacob,/_‘Seek me in emptiness, in dark nothingness.’/I am God. I work out in the open,/_saying what’s right, setting things right.

18582.text: /So gather around, come on in,/_all you refugees and castoffs./They don’t seem to know much, do they—/_those who carry around their no‐god blocks of wood,/_praying for help to a dead stick?

18583.text: /So tell me what you think. Look at the evidence./_Put your heads together. Make your case./Who told you, and a long time ago, what’s going on here?/_Who made sense of things for you?/Wasn’t I the one? God?/_It had to be me. I’m the only God there is—/The only God who does things right/_and knows how to help.

18584.text: /So turn to me and be helped—saved!—/_everyone, whoever and wherever you are./I am God,/_the only God there is, the one and only.

18585.text: /I promise in my own name:/_Every word out of my mouth does what it says./_I never take back what I say./Everyone is going to end up kneeling before me./_Everyone is going to end up saying of me,

18586.text: /_‘Yes! Salvation and strength are in God!’” ¶All who have raged against him/_will be brought before him,/_disgraced by their unbelief.

18587.text: /And all who are connected with Israel/_will have a robust, praising, good life in God!

18588.text: §¶The god Bel falls down, god Nebo slumps./_The no‐god hunks of wood are loaded on mules/And have to be hauled off,/_wearing out the poor mules—

18589.text: /Dead weight, burdens who can’t bear burdens,/_hauled off to captivity.

18590.text: ¶“Listen to me, family of Jacob,/_everyone that’s left of the family of Israel./I’ve been carrying you on my back/_from the day you were born,

18591.text: /And I’ll keep on carrying you when you’re old./_I’ll be there, bearing you when you’re old and gray./I’ve done it and will keep on doing it,/_carrying you on my back, saving you.

18592.text: ¶“So to whom will you compare me, the Incomparable?/_Can you picture me without reducing me?

18593.text: /People with a lot of money/_hire craftsmen to make them gods./The artisan delivers the god,/_and they kneel and worship it!

18594.text: /They carry it around in holy parades,/_then take it home and put it on a shelf./And there it sits, day in and day out,/_a dependable god, always right where you put it./Say anything you want to it, it never talks back./_Of course, it never does anything either!

18595.text: ¶“Think about this. Wrap your minds around it./_This is serious business, rebels. Take it to heart.

18596.text: /Remember your history,/_your long and rich history./I am God, the only God you’ve had or ever will have—/_incomparable, irreplaceable—

18597.text: /From the very beginning/_telling you what the ending will be,/All along letting you in/_on what is going to happen,/Assuring you, ‘I’m in this for the long haul,/_I’ll do exactly what I set out to do,’

18598.text: /Calling that eagle, Cyrus, out of the east,/_from a far country the man I chose to help me./I’ve said it, and I’ll most certainly do it./_I’ve planned it, so it’s as good as done.

18599.text: ¶“Now listen to me:/_You’re a hardheaded bunch and hard to help.

18600.text: /I’m ready to help you right now./_Deliverance is not a long‐range plan./_Salvation isn’t on hold./I’m putting salvation to work in Zion now,/_and glory in Israel.”

18601.text: §¶“Get off your high horse and sit in the dirt,/_virgin daughter of Babylon./No more throne for you—sit on the ground,/_daughter of the Chaldeans./Nobody will be calling you ‘charming’/_and ‘alluring’ anymore.

18602.text: Get used to it./Get a job, any old job:/_Clean gutters, scrub toilets./Hock your gowns and scarves,/_put on overalls—the party’s over.

18603.text: /Your nude body will be on public display,/_exposed to vulgar taunts./It’s vengeance time, and I’m taking vengeance./_No one gets let off the hook.”

18604.text: §¶Our Redeemer speaks,/_named God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies, The Holy of Israel:

18605.text: /“Shut up and get out of the way,/_daughter of Chaldeans./You’ll no longer be called/_‘First Lady of the Kingdoms.’

18606.text: /I was fed up with my people,/_thoroughly disgusted with my progeny./I turned them over to you,/_but you had no compassion./You put old men and women/_to cruel, hard labor.

18607.text: /You said, ‘I’m the First Lady./_I’ll always be the pampered darling.’/You took nothing seriously, took nothing to heart,/_never gave tomorrow a thought.

18608.text: /Well, start thinking, playgirl./_You’re acting like the center of the universe,/Smugly saying to yourself, ‘I’m Number One. There’s nobody but me./_I’ll never be a widow, I’ll never lose my children.’

18609.text: /Those two things are going to hit you both at once,/_suddenly, on the same day:/Spouse and children gone, a total loss,/_despite your many enchantments and charms.

18610.text: /You were so confident and comfortable in your evil life,/_saying, ‘No one sees me.’/You thought you knew so much, had everything figured out./_What delusion!/_Smugly telling yourself, ‘I’m Number One. There’s nobody but me.’

18611.text: /Ruin descends—/_you can’t charm it away./Disaster strikes—/_you can’t cast it off with spells./Catastrophe, sudden and total—/_and you’re totally at sea, totally bewildered!

18612.text: /But don’t give up. From your great repertoire/_of enchantments there must be one you haven’t yet tried./You’ve been at this a long time./_Surely something will work.

18613.text: /I know you’re exhausted trying out remedies,/_but don’t give up./Call in the astrologers and stargazers./_They’re good at this. Surely they can work up something!

18614.text: ¶“Fat chance. You’d be grasping at straws/_that are already in the fire,/A fire that is even now raging./_Your ‘experts’ are in it and won’t get out./It’s not a fire for cooking venison stew,/_not a fire to warm you on a winter night!

18615.text: /That’s the fate of your friends in sorcery, your magician buddies/_you’ve been in cahoots with all your life./They reel, confused, bumping into one another./_None of them bother to help you.”

18616.text: §¶“And now listen to this, family of Jacob,/_you who are called by the name Israel:/Who got you started in the loins of Judah,/_you who use God’s name to back up your promises/_and pray to the God of Israel?/But do you mean it?/_Do you live like it?

18617.text: /You claim to be citizens of the Holy City;/_you act as though you lean on the God of Israel,/_named God‐of‐the‐Angel‐Armies.

18618.text: /For a long time now, I’ve let you in on the way I work:/_I told you what I was going to do beforehand,/_then I did it and it was done, and that’s that.

18619.text: /I know you’re a bunch of hardheads,/_obstinate and flint‐faced,

18620.text: /So I got a running start and began telling you/_what was going on before it even happened./That is why you can’t say,/_‘My god‐idol did this.’/_‘My favorite god‐carving commanded this.’

18621.text: /You have all this evidence/_confirmed by your own eyes and ears./_Shouldn’t you be talking about it?/And that was just the beginning./_I have a lot more to tell you,/_things you never knew existed.

18622.text: /This isn’t a variation on the same old thing./_This is new, brand‐new,/_something you’d never guess or dream up./When you hear this you won’t be able to say,/_‘I knew that all along.’

18623.text: /You’ve never been good listeners to me./_You have a history of ignoring me,/A sorry track record of fickle attachments—/_rebels from the womb./But out of the sheer goodness of my heart,/_because of who I am,

18624.text: /I keep a tight rein on my anger and hold my temper./_I don’t wash my hands of you./Do you see what I’ve done?

18625.text: /_I’ve refined you, but not without fire./_I’ve tested you like silver in the furnace of affliction.

18626.text: /Out of myself, simply because of who I am, I do what I do./_I have my reputation to keep up./_I’m not playing second fiddle to either gods or people.

18627.text: ¶“Listen, Jacob. Listen, Israel—/_I’m the One who named you!/I’m the One./_I got things started and, yes, I’ll wrap them up.

18628.text: /Earth is my work, handmade./_And the skies—I made them, too, horizon to horizon./When I speak, they’re on their feet, at attention.

18629.text: ¶“Come everybody, gather around, listen:/_Who among the gods has delivered the news?/I, God, love this man Cyrus, and I’m using him/_to do what I want with Babylon.

18630.text: /I, yes I, have spoken. I’ve called him./_I’ve brought him here. He’ll be successful.

18631.text: /Come close, listen carefully:/_I’ve never kept secrets from you./_I’ve always been present with you.”  §¶And now, the Master, God, sends me and his Spirit

18632.text: /_with this Message from God,/_your Redeemer, The Holy of Israel:/“I am God, your God,/_who teaches you how to live right and well./_I show you what to do, where to go.

18633.text: /If you had listened all along to what I told you,/_your life would have flowed full like a river,/_blessings rolling in like waves from the sea.

18634.text: /Children and grandchildren are like sand,/_your progeny like grains of sand./There would be no end of them,/_no danger of losing touch with me.”

18635.text: ¶Get out of Babylon! Run from the Babylonians!/_Shout the news. Broadcast it./Let the world know, the whole world./_Tell them, “God redeemed his dear servant Jacob!”

18636.text: ¶They weren’t thirsty when he led them through the deserts./_He made water pour out of the rock;/_he split the rock and the water gushed.

18637.text: ¶“There is no peace,” says God, “for the wicked.”

18638.text: §¶Listen, far‐flung islands,/_pay attention, faraway people:/God put me to work from the day I was born./_The moment I entered the world he named me.

18639.text: /He gave me speech that would cut and penetrate./_He kept his hand on me to protect me./He made me his straight arrow/_and hid me in his quiver.

18640.text: /He said to me, “You’re my dear servant,/_Israel, through whom I’ll shine.”

18641.text: ¶But I said, “I’ve worked for nothing./_I’ve nothing to show for a life of hard work./Nevertheless, I’ll let God have the last word./_I’ll let him pronounce his verdict.”

18642.text: ¶“And now,” God says,/_this God who took me in hand/_from the moment of birth to be his servant,/To bring Jacob back home to him,/_to set a reunion for Israel—/What an honor for me in God’s eyes!/_That God should be my strength!

18643.text: /He says, “But that’s not a big enough job for my servant—/_just to recover the tribes of Jacob,/_merely to round up the strays of Israel./I’m setting you up as a light for the nations/_so that my salvation becomes global!”

18644.text: ¶God, Redeemer of Israel, The Holy of Israel,/_says to the despised one, kicked around by the nations,/_slave labor to the ruling class:/“Kings will see, get to their feet—the princes, too—/_and then fall on their faces in homage/Because of God, who has faithfully kept his word,/_The Holy of Israel, who has chosen you.”

18645.text: ¶God also says:¶“When the time’s ripe, I answer you./_When victory’s due, I help you./I form you and use you/_to reconnect the people with me,/To put the land in order,/_to resettle families on the ruined properties.

18646.text: /I tell prisoners, ‘Come on out. You’re free!’/_and those huddled in fear, ‘It’s all right. It’s safe now.’/_picnics on all the hills—

18647.text: /Nobody hungry, nobody thirsty,/_shade from the sun, shelter from the wind,/For the Compassionate One guides them,/_takes them to the best springs.

18648.text: /I’ll make all my mountains into roads,/_turn them into a superhighway.

18649.text: /There’ll be foodstands along all the roads,/Look: These coming from far countries,/_and those, out of the north,/These streaming in from the west,/_and those from all the way down the Nile!”

18650.text: ¶Heavens, raise the roof! Earth, wake the dead!/_Mountains, send up cheers!/God has comforted his people./_He has tenderly nursed his beaten‐up, beaten‐down people.

18651.text: ¶But Zion said, “I don’t get it. God has left me./_My Master has forgotten I even exist.”

18652.text: ¶“Can a mother forget the infant at her breast,/_walk away from the baby she bore?/But even if mothers forget,/_I’d never forget you—never.

18653.text: /Look, I’ve written your names on the backs of my hands./_The walls you’re rebuilding are never out of my sight.

18654.text: /Your builders are faster than your wreckers./_The demolition crews are gone for good.

18655.text: /Look up, look around, look well!/_See them all gathering, coming to you?/As sure as I am the living God”—God’s Decree—/_“you’re going to put them on like so much jewelry,/_you’re going to use them to dress up like a bride.

18656.text: ¶“And your ruined land?/_Your devastated, decimated land?/Filled with more people than you know what to do with!/_And your barbarian enemies, a fading memory.

18657.text: /The children born in your exile will be saying,/_‘It’s getting too crowded here. I need more room.’/And you’ll say to yourself,
